docs.lead_paragraph: HEDGE FUND RULES -- The Bush administration said that there was no need for greater government oversight of the rapidly growing hedge fund industry and other private investment groups. It announced instead an agreement on a set of nonbinding principles. [Page A1.] EXECUTIVES LEAVE BANK -- The deterioration in the United States mortgage market has forced the departures of two top executives at HSBC Holdings. The departures come after HSBC surprised investors by announcing that it needed to increase its reserves for bad loans. [C1.] MICROSOFT LOSES PATENT CASE -- A federal jury ordered Microsoft to pay $1.52 billion in a patent dispute over the MP3 format, which is at the heart of the digital music boom. If upheld, the patent judgment would be the largest on record. [C1.] LABOR BILL -- Organized labor is fighting for a pro-union bill as if its life depended on it. The bill would make it far easier for workers to join unions, through a process known as a card check or majority signup. [A18.] OIL-FOR-FOOD SENTENCE -- In federal court in Manhattan, Tongsun Park, a South Korean businessman convicted of illegally representing Saddam Hussein in the United Nations' oil-for-food program for Iraq, was sentenced to five years in prison. [A10.] THE AMERICAN WAY -- With recent changes, start-ups are no longer rare in France and elsewhere in Europe. And Europe's new entrepreneurs are turning west, to learn the start-up culture bred in Silicon Valley. [C1.] NEW COOL -- Until recently, it looked as if the depleted ozone layer protecting the earth from harmful solar rays was on its way to being healed. But thanks in part to an explosion of demand for air-conditioners in places like India and China, the ozone layer is proving very hard to repair. [C1.] OPTIONS BACKDATING -- Lawyers and executives have watched the case of Brocade Communications to see how government investigations into stock option backdating will play out. But Brocade's $7 million settlement has offered little guidance. [C2.] CBS CABLE DEAL -- CBS announced it had concluded a series of agreements in which cable systems will compensate the network for the right to carry its programming. [C3.] BUILDING ON MYSPACE -- Fox Interactive Media, the News Corporation unit that operates MySpace, said it had acquired the Strategic Data Corporation, an advertising technology company, to help increase revenue from the popular Web site. [C7.] IRAN RATTLES MARKET -- Wall Street turned in a mixed performance as Iran's refusal to suspend uranium enrichment rattled investors and tempered a tech rally. The Dow fell 52.39 points, to 12,686.02. [C9.] FORECAST HITS PENNEY SHARES -- J. C. Penney reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings, but its shares fell sharply after it forecast a first-quarter profit below Wall Street estimates. [C4.] THE WAIT AT CHRYSLER -- A week after DaimlerChrysler signaled its plans to put the Chrysler Group on the auction block, an e-mail message sent to employees by Chrysler's chief executive, Thomas W. LaSorda, above, indicated it might be weeks or months before the automaker's future can be determined. [C3.] CANCER DRUG TEST -- Genentech said a low dose of its cancer drug Avastin worked just as well as a high dose in a clinical trial. Its shares fell amid concern that it would receive less revenue from the drug. [C7.] EXECUTIVES INDICTED -- Three executives of a cleaning and maintenance company, Rosenbaum-Cunningham International, were indicted on charges of defrauding the federal government of taxes owed on behalf of illegal immigrant workers. [A18.] AIRLINES ADDRESS RUNWAY DELAYS -- Working to head off passenger-rights legislation, the Air Transport Association, a trade group for United States airlines, has suggested voluntary fixes for long runway delays. [C9.] AMONG GENTLEMEN -- To help commemorate its 50th anniversary, GQ magazine is starting a charitable project called the Gentlemen's Fund. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C4.] ONLINE LEFT HOLDING THE BAG -- When a fast-food chain runs into trouble, franchise owners often take the hardest hit. A special report on Small Business is at nytimes.com/business. YOUR TAXES -- Suggestions on surviving an audit, and tax tips on pleasing Uncle Sam. A special report is at nytimes.com/business. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. Gamco Investors, the asset manager headed by Mario Gabelli, said on Thursday it offered to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into mutual fund share trading and, as a result, has increased its legal and regulatory reserves by $3 million. (REUTERS) Johnson & Johnson's Centocor unit received a subpoena in connection with an investigation into pricing of its drug Remicade, a treatment for rheumatoid arthritis and other inflammatory diseases. docs.lead_paragraph: Hollywood studios are going into business with one of their biggest tormentors: the peer-to-peer pioneer BitTorrent. On Monday, the company, whose technology unleashed a wave of illegal file-sharing on the Internet, plans to unveil the BitTorrent Entertainment Network on its Web site, BitTorrent.com. The digital media store will offer around 3,000 new and classic movies and thousands more television shows, as well as a thousand PC games and music videos each, all legally available for purchase.

docs.lead_paragraph: Keeping track of constant changes in airline frequent-flier and other travel-loyalty programs makes me feel as if my head is about to explode. docs.lead_paragraph: COUNT THE REASONS -- A caldron of investors' concerns -- from a slowing American economy to a faltering mortgage market and the tightening of historically easy credit -- has been bubbling up over the last year and appears to have set off the wave of selling that rocked world financial markets this week. [Page C1.] INSIDER TRADING SCHEME CITED -- Federal authorities accused 13 people of taking part in what they called one of the most far-reaching insider trading schemes on Wall Street in decades, involving investment banks and a web of hedge funds, day traders, lawyers and even a few supervisors. [C1.] DEFENDING AGAINST CHINA TRADE -- A paper mill in Maryland's Appalachians, the area's last remaining big factory, may become a line in the sand as the Commerce Department decides whether to impose duties on high-gloss paper -- the kind made at the mill -- that is imported from China. [A1.] PROTECTIONISM'S TOLL -- Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said that the economy was slowing toward moderate and sustained growth, but warned it could be derailed if trade barriers were raised.[C7.] WAL-MART'S FOCUS -- ''Saving people money so they can live better lives.'' This new, and so far internal, definition of what Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer, stands for will soon become a very public strategy, evident on the shelves of 4,000 stores and in advertisements seen across the country. [C1.] ROUGH QUARTER FOR DELL -- Dell's inability to capture sales in the booming notebook computer market was reflected in its fourth-quarter financial results. Dell said net income fell by a third, and revenue fell 5.1 percent. The last time revenue declined at Dell was in 2001, in the recession that followed the technology boom. [C3.] YOUTUBE'S PARTNERSHIPS -- Google has been frustrated in its efforts to reach comprehensive deals with major studios and networks to put their video on YouTube, but it is forming partnerships with hundreds of smaller media companies [C1.] JOB OPENING IN OMAHA -- Warren Buffett, chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, said in his letter to shareholders that he is seeking a new candidate to become chief investment officer when he steps down. [C3.] CHEVY TRUCK EDGES F-SERIES -- General Motors surprised the auto industry by posting a sales increase in February, when its new Chevrolet Silverado pickup unseated the Ford F-series for the title of best-selling vehicle. [C3.] RETAILERS IN DIFFERENT DIRECTIONS -- Sears Holdings and Kohl's both reported higher quarterly earnings, but the struggling retailer Gap Inc. reported that its fourth-quarter profit fell 35 percent. ''We were not satisfied with our 2006 results and are taking action,'' said Gap's chairman, Robert J. Fisher, above, who is serving as the company's interim chief executive [C6.] EUROPEANS VS. MICROSOFT -- The European Commission has threatened Microsoft with millions of euros in new fines in a long-running antitrust dispute, saying the company was demanding unreasonable royalties from rivals seeking to link their software to the Windows operating system. [C3.] EARNINGS PLUNGE FOR TELEKOM -- Deutsche Telekom, the largest European telephone company, posted a fourth-quarter loss of nearly 900 million euros ($1.18 billion) as it lost customers in its home market, prompting the company to look abroad for growth. [C2.] TV SCREENS EVERYWHERE -- Digital TV networks are popping up on screens in groceries, office buildings, retail stores, on gas pumps, and, well, just about every place imaginable. Advertisers are trying to reach consumers where they cannot avoid ads. Advertising. [C6.] DOING GOOD, IN PINSTRIPES -- Hedge funds are known for secrecy and a ruthless focus on profitability. But there is a growing number of charities within the $1.3 trillion world of hedge funds. [C5.] RATS' IMPACT -- New York City officials shut three Pizza Hut restaurants operated by the same franchisee that owns the KFC/Taco Bell in Manhattan that became infamous when television cameras captured a swarm of rats inside. Yum Brands, the parent company of Taco Bell, KFC and Pizza Hut, said it was closing 10 other restaurants owned by the franchisee. docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN the dust finally settled on the 2006 holiday buying season, American consumers -- who braved long lines, cold weather and possibly a few kicks to the shins -- had spent $3.7 billion on new video-game consoles and software. And while the more than two million youngsters (and not-so-youngsters) who discovered a next-generation gaming system under the Christmas tree -- a Microsoft Xbox 360, a Sony PlayStation 3 or a Nintendo Wii -- represent a substantial user base for these platforms, they mean even more to the entertainment industry as a whole. To the makers of these video-game systems and to a growing number of film and television studios, they represent a significant new audience for full-length movies and television shows that can be downloaded directly to gaming consoles. In late November Microsoft began expanding the library on its Xbox Live network, a broadband service available by subscription to Xbox 360 owners. In addition to the video-game trailers and playable demonstrations that the network has traditionally offered, you can now find an eclectically selected collection of films and television shows offered for downloading to a console's hard drive: for a few dollars you can view ''Mission: Impossible III'' or ''Chinatown'' or the episode of ''Chappelle's Show'' with the blind white supremacist, on your television, just as if you were watching a DVD or a video-on-demand channel.

headline.main: Selling 'Zoolander' to the Gears-of-Warriors

docs.abstract: Microsoft has introduced XBox Live network, broadband service available by subscription to XBox 360 owners, which offers eclectically selective collection of films and television shows for downloading; Microsoft hopes X-Box Live will replace other sources of home viewing products, although limited offerings have generated little interest; Sony hopes to offer similar programming with its PlayStation 3, but Nintendo has no such plans for its Wii game console; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Makers of gaming consoles want part of the on-demand-video future.

docs.lead_paragraph: ALL good things must end, and if the bull market has run its course, which seems distinctly possible after this week's trading, the descent will be steeper for some types of stocks than others. If a protracted decline has begun, one investment adviser is warning his clients, the sharpest reversals of fortune could be experienced in what have been some of the hottest sectors. The best market performers in the six months before the market's latest peak have been involved in information technology, industrial materials and manufacturing consumer discretionary items like cars, luxury goods and clothing. James Stack, editor of the InvesTech Market Analyst newsletter and a diligent student of market history, points out that these groups have borne the brunt of declines since the early 1970s.

headline.main: Finding Safe Picks In a Downturn

docs.lead_paragraph: Reaching out to millions of aspiring game developers around the world, Microsoft plans today to announce a contest that will award $10,000 and the opportunity to entice millions of eyeballs to the next great digital diversion for the company's Xbox 360. In addition to the game console's snazzy graphics, the Xbox Live online service has been the most important component of the Xbox 360's success since its debut in 2005. And perhaps the most popular aspect of Xbox Live has been the service's arcade component, which allows users to download and play smaller, relatively simpler games like Uno and Geometry Wars that usually cost less than $10. (By contrast, top-end games can sell in stores for around $60.)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, when Congress passed a law to extend daylight saving time by a month, the move seemed a harmless step that would let the nation burn a little less fossil fuel and enjoy a bit more sunshine. Representative Fred Upton, a Michigan Republican, predicted that children would rejoice at the prospect of an extra hour of daylight trick-or-treating on Halloween. But there is no rejoicing among corporate technology managers.

headline.main: Time Change A 'Mini-Y2K' In Tech Terms

docs.snippet: Companies are scrambling to reset computing devices as daylight saving time begins three weeks earlier.

docs.lead_paragraph: ADVERTISING and eyeballs were two nouns linked in my mind well before Internet marketers started spouting them. I always associate them with the reference in ''The Great Gatsby'' to the dilapidated billboard with the all-seeing eyes of Dr. T. J. Eckleburg -- an image that literature professors swoon over, but which I tend to ascribe to F. Scott Fitzgerald's probably sipping immoderately from a flask of whiskey while spotting an actual abandoned billboard on a drive to Long Island Sound. This, however, brings travel into the mix. Advertising, eyeballs and travel. Somebody has figured out that those three concepts are linked every time we get on an airplane. And now, perhaps inexorably, the spirit of Dr. T. J. Eckleburg's eyeballs peers up from the little billboard of an airline tray table.

docs.lead_paragraph: Most music phones so far have been an amalgam of two disparate technologies, but the Nokia 5300 XpressMusic may be on the verge of getting it right. Many cellphones have music-playing software, but the 5300 also has buttons on the outside for playing, pausing, rewinding and fast-forwarding tracks. The two-inch screen slides up to reveal a full keypad, and the phone is compatible with AOL, Yahoo and MSN Instant Messaging, as well as myFaves, T-Mobile's free calling plan for friends and family.

docs.lead_paragraph: Could no one come up with a better title for an action game featuring a gun-toting sorceress than Bullet Witch, from Cavia? I'll admit the title is very clear, like a restaurant called the Tasty Food Diner, but does one really need a title that screams out, ''Look, this game has witches! And guns! How cool is that!''? Of course, it is pretty darn cool. There is something inherently appealing about a sexy, buxom witch wandering a postapocalyptic landscape shooting zombies with flaming bullets and casting spells that bring down lightning or cause spears to shoot from the ground.

headline.main: A Sexy Witch, Zombies and Death: Who Needs a Story?

docs.abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory column reviews video games Bullet Witch, developed by Cavia and published by Atari for Xbox 360, and Def Jam: Icon, developed by EA Chicago and published by Electronic Arts for Playstation 3 and Xbox 360; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Story aside, Bullet Witch is reasonably entertaining, with a plethora of zombies occasionally aided by giant-brained creatures and 50-foot monsters.

docs.lead_paragraph: Moving to enhance its PlayStation 3 game console, Sony today plans to announce new online capabilities for it, meant to draw gamers into Sony's cyberspace community and allow them to share entertainment content they have created, à la YouTube. The centerpiece, a new service called PlayStation Home, is to become available to consumers in the fall, said senior game industry executives, who requested anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss the plans. PlayStation Home is meant to build on and surpass somewhat similar offerings from Sony's competitors Microsoft and Nintendo by allowing users to create persisting online identities that record players' achievements in different games. As players progress through a game, they will unlock various virtual prizes that they can then show off to friends and rivals, the executives said.

headline.main: Sony to Add Online Bells and Whistles for PlayStation 3

docs.abstract: Sony is set to announce online capabilities for its PlayStation 3 game console that are meant to draw gamers into Sony's cyberspace community and allow them to share entertainment content they have created; PlayStation Home service will become available in fall 2007; photo (M)
docs.snippet: New online capabilities are meant to allow gamers to share content they have created, à la YouTube.

docs.lead_paragraph: Updating Devices For Daylight Saving Q. My computer is set to adjust itself automatically for daylight saving time, but since the starting and ending dates for daylight time are changing this year, do I need to adjust my system clock manually? A. You can make manual adjustments, but if you use Windows XP, Service Pack 2 -- or Mac OS X 10.3 and later -- and keep your system current with all the latest updates, your computer has probably been fixed to reflect the new dates, including the start of daylight time this Sunday. Windows Vista does not need updating. For older operating systems, Microsoft has links to resources at support.microsoft.com/gp/cp--dst and Apple has its page of information for Mac at docs.info.apple.com/article.html?artnum=305056.

docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft said it had signed its first agreement to license its technology, almost three years after European Union antitrust regulators ordered the software company to share data to increase competition. Microsoft said the deal, with Quest Software of California, was meant to comply with an antitrust order issued in March 2004 that demanded licensing of software that helps desktop computers communicate with servers. But the deal was met with skepticism from adversaries, who questioned how a company with a longstanding relationship with Microsoft could be considered a rival. The European Commission threatened Microsoft last week with fines as high as 3 million euros ($3.9 million) a day for failing to comply with the order. THOMAS CRAMPTON

docs.lead_paragraph: Two operating systems run more than 95 percent of the world's computers, but dozens of systems are behind the 2.5 billion mobile phones in circulation, a situation that has hampered the growth of new services, industry executives and independent specialists say. ''There are too many operating systems already and more are coming on stream, making things complicated for smaller software companies,'' said Tony Cripps, a senior analyst with the telecommunications consulting firm Ovum in London.

headline.main: As Mobile Phones Grow More Complex, Carriers Insist on Fewer Operating Systems

docs.abstract: Mobile phone carries seek fewer operating systems powering 2.5 billion phones currently in circulation; say increasing complexity of devices is creating difficulties for software developers that are forced to deal with dozens of systems to ensure compatibility; multiple systems are time-consuming and expensive for carriers which must configure phones for their services (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft announced yesterday that it was extending the online gaming service for its Xbox consoles to the millions of people who use Windows PCs to play games over the Internet, a move that could bolster the popularity -- and profits -- of video gaming. Xbox Live, Microsoft's online gaming network that serves some six million Xbox users, is scheduled on May 8 to open its basic and premium features to online PC gamers under the rubric of Games for Windows -- Live, Microsoft executives said.

docs.lead_paragraph: ECHOES OF A RECENT BOOM Many technology veterans of Silicon Valley's dot-com era have regrouped and found a new mission in alternative energy: developing wind power, solar panels, ethanol plants and hydrogen-powered cars. [Page A1.] VIACOM TAKES ON GOOGLE Viacom, the parent of MTV, Nickelodeon and Comedy Central, filed a lawsuit accusing Google of ''massive copyright infringement'' on its YouTube site. Viacom said it was seeking more than $1 billion in damages. [C1.] FORECLOSURES POINT THE WAY DOWN Stocks fell broadly and sharply after a report on mortgage defaults indicated that the troubled housing market will weaken further before showing signs of improvement. [C1.] IMPACT OF SUBPRIME TURMOIL Mutual funds held mortgage-related debt securities issued by subprime lenders New Century Financial, Novastar Financial and others at the end of last year, indicating that everyday investors are among those who will likely be hurt by the turmoil that is tearing through the residential mortgage market. [C1.] SPYING CASE LINGERS Hewlett-Packard executives would normally have a lot to crow about at today's annual meeting, including rising profit margins across the company. But last fall's revelations of a boardroom meltdown cast a long shadow. [C1.] IT GOES DOWN EASY Folgers has opened a new flank in the coffee wars by offering a ''stomach friendly'' coffee for consumers who think they can no longer handle the hard stuff. [C1.] TURNING OFF THE LIGHT A coalition of industrialists, environmentalists and energy specialists is banding together to try to eliminate the incandescent light bulb in about 10 years and replace it with alternatives that are more efficient and last longer. [C3.] PROFIT UP 29 PERCENT Goldman Sachs reported a 29 percent increase in profit for its first quarter, setting a record amid growing concern on Wall Street over falling stock prices and an imploding subprime mortgage market. The firm reported profit of $3.2 billion, or $6.67 a share, for the quarter that ended before the recent market slump and the problems involving subprime lenders. [C3.] ADMINISTRATION'S NEW ATTITUDE Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. suggested that the administration was considering a more business-friendly approach, a response to criticism that post-Enron rule changes had gone too far. [C3.] LEHMAN INVESTS IN HEDGE FUND Lehman Brothers, bought a 20 percent stake in the management companies of D. E. Shaw, a $29 billion hedge fund. The acquisition continued Lehman's strategy of buying stakes in hedge funds to gain exposure to the fast-growing alternative asset arena. For David Shaw, above, who has watched his company grow from $28 million in 1988 to $29 billion today, the deal was probably a way to diversify his wealth. [C2.] DISC WITH MEDICAL DATA MISSING WellPoint, one of the nation's largest health insurers, has begun notifying 75,000 members of its Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield unit in New York, that a compact disc holding their sensitive medical and other personal information has disappeared. [C2.] EX-SIEMENS MANAGERS ON TRIAL Two former managers for Siemens told a German court that they participated in paying bribes of roughly 6 million euros in Italy as part of the company's plan to anchor itself in the booming market for power generation equipment. [C9.] XBOX ONLINE SERVICE FOR PC'S TOO Microsoft announced that it was extending the online gaming service for its Xbox consoles to the millions of people who use Windows PCs to play games over the Internet. [C3.] THE HUMOR IS LOST Washington Mutual has stopped running a commercial that showed actors playing bankers poised atop a building as if about to jump, the latest spot to be pulled in a backlash against advertising with suicide themes. Advertising: Stuart Elliot. [C8.] AN OIL CITY IN BLOOM Houston has shaken off the effects of the Enron implosion six years ago and is enjoying its strongest resurgence in more than 20 years, galvanized by record profits at energy companies. [C6.] A BID TO CUT CARBON EMISSIONS Britain is proposing laws to enforce a cut in carbon emissions, in this case, a 60 percent decrease by 2050. [A13.] HAUTE CUISINE IN ROOM 932 More hotels are aiming and claiming to provide room service on a higher plane. But are they succeeding? The Times's restaurant critic packed a bag and endeavored to find out. [F1.] RIGHTS TO SIMPSON BOOK The rights to the aborted O. J. Simpson book, ''If I Did It,'' should be auctioned so the family of the murder victim Ronald L. Goldman will receive the proceeds from the sale of the rights, a judge in Los Angeles ruled. [A16.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. THE COSMETICS MAKER REVLON posted a fourth-quarter loss, in contrast to a year-ago profit, as sales dropped and the company had costs associated with a revamping program. (REUTERS)

docs.lead_paragraph: When I was growing up, my friends and I lamented that no matter where we went, it seemed that the best stuff wouldn't happen until we were about to leave. You spend a couple of weeks at summer camp and only in the final days do you realize that the counselors leave a certain very important door unlocked. And you think, ''Wow, this is awesome; but why couldn't it have been this way the whole time?'' That is exactly how I've felt playing God of War II, the luscious, stunningly well-designed mythological action game that delivers a glorious swan song for Sony's PlayStation 2, the world's best-selling game console. Sony has sold many more than 100 million PS2s since the system's introduction seven years ago, and since then more than 1,000 games have been released for it in North America. You could argue that God of War II, released on Tuesday, is not only better than all of them but is also perhaps the best single-player action-adventure game yet made for any console.

headline.main: A Game With New Tricks for an Old System

docs.abstract: God of War II for PlayStation 2 is mythological action game that acts as swan song for system that will soon be replaced by Sony's PlayStation 3; although Sony is pushing PlayStation 3, God of War II is far more complex and well made game than any that has been produced for new system; photo (M)
docs.snippet: This luscious, stunningly well-designed mythological action game delivers a glorious swan song for Sony’s PlayStation 2, the world’s best-selling game console.

docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Tellme Networks to add voice-recognition software that lets users obtain a phone listing, order a pizza and search the Internet. Financial terms were not disclosed, but the deal was said to be worth more than $800 million, making it Microsoft's biggest acquisition since 2002.

docs.lead_paragraph: WARNING FOR SLEEPING PILLS -- The most widely prescribed sleeping pills, including Ambien and Lunesta, can cause strange behavior like driving and eating while asleep, the Food and Drug Administration said, announcing that strong new warnings would be placed on the labels of 13 drugs. [Page A1.] G.M.'S MIXED PICTURE -- General Motors reported its largest quarterly profit in two and a half years. But it still lost $2 billion last year, the second consecutive year of multibillion-dollar losses. Market Place. [C1.] CHARGES DROPPED IN H.P. CASE -- A judge dismissed charges against Patricia C. Dunn, the former chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard, in a corporate spying case that gained national attention. H.P.'s shareholders, at their annual meeting, appeared to give Mark V. Hurd, the new chairman, a vote of confidence and indicated they felt that last year's problems were now behind the company. [C1.] H&R BLOCK'S SUBPRIME PROBLEM -- The tax-preparation giant H&R Block became another victim of problems plaguing the subprime mortgage industry, reporting quarterly losses of $60 million. [C1.] HARVARD'S INVESTOR -- Mohamed El-Erian, who manages Harvard University's $30 billion endowment, has brought an international flair and bond expertise to the job since arriving one year ago. [C1.] A BID TO CURB A REFRIGERANT -- A coalition of industrial and developing countries has begun pushing for stringent limits on the world's most popular refrigerant for air-conditioners, as evidence mounts that it harms the earth's ozone layer and contributes to global warming. [C3.] A CLEANER COAL-FIRED PLANT -- American Electric Power, a major electric utility, is planning the largest demonstration yet of capturing carbon dioxide from a coal-fired power plant and pumping it deep underground. [C3.] IMPORTS DOWN; EXPORTS UP -- The current-account deficit shrank in the fourth quarter of 2006 to its smallest in more than a year as lower oil prices took a bite out of imports and exports continued to rise. [C4.] CANCELING A CONTRACT -- The Coast Guard said it was canceling a contract with Lockheed Martin and Northrop Grumman to develop a vessel for a range of missions. [A25.] MISSING MEDICAL DATA FOUND -- A missing compact disc containing sensitive medical and personal information on 75,000 Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield members was recovered. [C2.] AVON'S AT THE DOOR -- Avon, the cosmetics retailer known for the perky commercials that began with the ringing of a doorbell followed by the words ''Avon calling,'' is now starting the largest campaign in its 121-year history. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C4.] NATIONAL MAGAZINE AWARDS -- The finalists for the National Magazine Award for general excellence were announced, and among the publications in the running is The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, the journal with the so-called Doomsday Clock on the cover. [C4.] BLAME THE HEDGE FUNDS -- The recent volatility and pullback in Asian markets have prompted some investors to sound a familiar refrain: It's all the fault of the hedge funds. [C9.] DOW ENDS UP -- Wall Street closed with a respectable advance, though the Dow Jones industrial average initially fell as much as 136 points, and briefly dropped below 12,000. [C11.] LEHMAN PROFIT UP 5.6 PERCENT -- Lehman Brothers Holdings, the global investment bank, said that robust trading and overseas expansion drove its first-quarter profit up 5.6 percent, matching Wall Street's expectations. [C4.] A STEP TOWARD PRIVACY -- Google said it would take steps to make anonymous the logs its keeps of all searches that people conduct. [C4.] SEARCHING VIA SPOKEN WORD -- Microsoft said that it had agreed to buy Tellme Networks and its voice-recognition software. The purchase gives Microsoft voice-recognition programs it can combine with mobile phone applications. Steven A. Ballmer, above, the Microsoft chief executive, said that search on cellphones would be a battlegrounds between Microsoft and Google. [C5.] GOOGLE COMES TO TOWN -- Residents of Lenoir, N.C., an Appalachian furniture-making area that has lost thousands of jobs, may have gotten some good news: Google is building a ''server farm,'' a building full of computers, in their town. [A18.] HELP WANTED UNDER THE HOOD -- There are not enough qualified auto mechanics in New York, in part because the rapid computerization of car engines that has prompted many senior mechanics to retire. So the city's Department of Education and union leaders are holding free classes for anyone who wants to learn the trade. [B1.] ONLINE ALL ABOUT EXECUTIVE PAY -- Sumner M. Redstone's compensation for his role as chairman of CBS will be reduced after a shareholder lawsuit. At Citigroup, Charles O. Prince was paid $25.98 million for his work in 2006, an increase of about 13 percent over 2005. More news about executive pay packages and interactive features are in a special section on executive pay at nytimes.com/business. WEEKEND BUSINESS -- In a podcast, reporters and editors from The Times's Sunday Business section offer perspective on the week in business and beyond. Information on subscribing is at nytimes.com/business.

docs.lead_paragraph: Web search companies collect records of the searches that people conduct, a fact that has long generated fears among privacy advocates and some Internet users that valuable personal data could be misused. Now Google is taking a step to ease those concerns. The company keeps logs of all searches, along with digital identifiers linking them to specific computers and Internet browsers. It said on Wednesday that it would start to make those logs anonymous after 18 to 24 months, making it much harder to connect search records to a person. Under current practices, the company keeps the logs intact indefinitely.

headline.main: Google Adds A Safeguard On Privacy For Searchers

docs.abstract: Google says it will start to make logs of all searches anonymous after 18 to 24 months, making it much harder to connect search records to person; company keeps logs intact indefinitely; it is unclear whether change will have intended effect; privacy advocates react with mix of praise and dismay to policy change (M)
docs.snippet: Google is taking steps to make anonymous the logs it keeps of all searches that people conduct.

docs.lead_paragraph: Installing Adobe Reader Q. I can't seem to download Adobe Acrobat so I can print some rebate forms. What can I do? A. Adobe makes several programs that can read Portable Document Format (PDF) files, a format used for everything from official tax forms from the I.R.S. to newsletters, rebate forms and magazines. Adobe Acrobat and Adobe Reader (formerly called Adobe Acrobat Reader) are the two main programs the company offers for working with PDF files, but there are several differences between them to keep in mind.

docs.lead_paragraph: Almost 40 years ago, when Irene Marsh was a young woman, she took a few months of computer science courses. But when Ms. Marsh realized that would not help her find a job in this Appalachian furniture region, she dropped out and went to work in a factory making tabletops. Then, like thousands of other furniture makers here in the last five years, she lost her job to workers overseas, after 37 years at one company. But Ms. Marsh, who recently sat with a mouse and keyboard in a basic-skills classroom at Caldwell Community College a few miles south of here, may yet have her chance at a computer job.

headline.main: Google Is Reviving Hopes For Ex-Furniture Makers

docs.abstract: Google's plan for 'server farm' in Lenoir, NC, promises employment to some of people whose jobs at area's furniture factories were lost to workers overseas; 'server farm,' building full of computers that will become part of Google's worldwide network, would take advantage of region's underused electric power grid, cheap land and robust water supply; choice of Lenoir bodes well for other struggling manufacturing economies in South; photos; map (M)
docs.snippet: The Internet search giant announced that it would build a “server farm” in North Carolina where land is cheap.

docs.lead_paragraph: LOVERS do it. Athletes, too. And even students, cramming for exams. They all take pills to enhance their performance. To some degree, many a worker involved in creative activity does, too, but with cups of strong coffee from the corner Starbucks or the employee snack room. ''Caffeine is now a gateway drug'' that leads to a universe of ingestible mental enhancers, says Alex Soojung-Kim Pang, a futurist and science historian in Menlo Park, Calif. ''I foresee a day when the office medicine chest holds much more than aspirin.''

headline.main: Is the Key to Creativity in Your Pillbox, or in Your PC?

docs.abstract: G Pascal Zachary column on unspoken race between Big Pharma and Big Computing to decide which technology--electronic or biochemical--can be first to deliver magic elixer that gives humans vastly improved creative powers; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: The gap between what the Internet promises and what it delivers is part of the reason that people continue to turn to enhancers from caffeine to maca to virtual reality.

docs.lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of junk Web pages, created only to lure search-engine users to advertisements, are proliferating like billboards strung along freeways. Now Microsoft researchers say they have traced the companies and techniques behind them. A technical paper published by the researchers says the links promoting such pages are generated by a small group of shadowy operators apparently with the acquiescence of some major advertisers, Web page hosts and advertising syndicators. The report is available at www.cs.ucdavis.edu/hchen/paper/www07.pdf

headline.main: Researchers Track Down a Plague of Fake Web Pages

docs.lead_paragraph: OFFER FOR ABN AMRO -- Barclays, Britain's third-largest bank, has made an informal takeover offer for ABN Amro, the largest bank in the Netherlands, which is under pressure from hedge funds to consider a merger or asset sales to bolster its lagging share price. [Page C1.] UPFRONT WITH NICKELODEON -- Nickelodeon, a Viacom unit, was the first of many television networks promoting their digital ventures this spring as advertising executives determine how to spend their clients' budgets at the annual previews known as the upfronts. Viacom also has a lot of content appealing to younger viewers, like ''The Colbert Report,'' starring Stephen Colbert, above. [C1.] VENTURE CAPITAL FOR FILMS -- A fledgling film-financing company called Media Rights Capital may help shift the balance of power in Hollywood by increasing opportunity for idiosyncratic movies like the multilingual ''Babel,'' and by giving filmmakers and stars more earning power and ownership of their projects. [C1.] MUCH ANTICIPATION, FEW DETAILS -- Wall Street investors may be disappointed at what few details they discover from the Blackstone Group's prospectus if the firm decides to go ahead with the initial public offering it is said to be considering. [C3.] WEBCASTERS PROTEST A RULING -- Several Internet radio companies are arguing that a recent decision by the Copyright Royalty Board that they must pay royalties when users listen to a song would make it almost impossible for them to stay afloat. [C4.] A DISLIKED DATING SITE -- True.com has seemingly come out of nowhere to become one of the most visited sites in the $700 million-a-year online dating industry, drawing in 3.8 million people last month. But its provocative ads have made it controversial: ''loathed by everybody,'' is how one industry insider puts it. [C1.] NEWSPAPER FACES LABOR SUIT -- The National Labor Relations Board will prosecute The Santa Barbara News-Press for firing eight reporters from its newsroom, the agency announced. [C3.] TRACKING SPAM WEB PAGES -- Tens of thousands of junk Web pages, created only to lure search-engine users to advertisements, are proliferating like billboards strung along freeways. Now Microsoft researchers say they have traced the companies and techniques behind them. [C4.] ADS IN THE FORM OF 'LOST' KEYS -- At a modest cost, Nissan hopes to promote its 2007 Nissan Altima sedan by ''losing'' 20,000 key rings in bars, concert halls, sports arenas and other public places in seven large urban markets. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C5.] AMAZON, THE SYMPHONY STORE -- Amazon.com, the Internet merchant, has opened a classical music discount store. Thomas May, Amazon's senior music editor, above, says that classical music is one of the fastest-growing music genres on the site. [C4.] TOBACCO COMPANY REJECTS BID -- Imperial Tobacco of Britain said that it would continue ''friendly'' efforts to buy Altadis, a rival based in Spain that rejected its initial offer of 45 euros a share. [C2.] BRAVO TO BUY A WEB SITE -- Bravo, a division of NBC Universal, is buying Television Without Pity, the television review Web site that has bitingly criticized the network's shows. [C4.] CHOICES MEAN REPEAT BUYERS -- Consumers are more likely to repurchase products when the initial buying experience is packed with ''superfluous choices'' -- like the color of a CD case. [C3.]

docs.lead_paragraph: YOU know the old drinker's saying that it is always 5 o'clock somewhere? Coors is turning back the clock seven minutes in an effort to turn the clock forward when it comes to reaching consumers through new media. For the Coors Light beer brand, the Adolph Coors Brewing Company division of Molson Coors is planning an interactive initiative, scheduled to start in mid-April, that promotes 4:53 p.m. as the new 5 o'clock.

headline.main: Cue the 4:53 Silver Bullet to Happy Hour

The Home Premium edition of Windows Vista has been added to the $1,300 Q1P, available now, and its enhanced handwriting recognition should make it easier to use the seven-inch screen as an input device.

docs.lead_paragraph: APPLE will not release the iPhone until June, but Leander Kahney, the writer of ''The Cult of Mac'' blog, posited this week on Wired News that the new phone is already partly responsible for a major change in how the company is perceived (wired.com). After nearly three decades, Apple is finally being taken seriously not just by the true believers, but by just about everybody. According to Mr. Kahney, this shift has taken place in the last few weeks, as both the iPhone and, more recently, Apple TV, have quickly become ''must have'' products. ''A lot of people thought Apple got lucky with the iPod,'' Mr. Kahney wrote. ''It was a one-hit wonder, a fluke not likely to be repeated.'' But the iPhone is already thought of as an ''industry-changing smash hit,'' and Apple TV, which at first drew shrugs, now may even eclipse the iPhone, according to the predictions of some (though by no means many) people (ipodnn.com).

headline.main: Apple Cult Becoming a Religion

docs.lead_paragraph: It is referred to as the last beachfront property in the wireless world -- a prized swath of spectrum that is about to be sold at federal auction. And it has touched off an intense lobbying effort pitting cellular companies against a variety of new players interested in the potential of a next-generation mobile Internet. The Federal Communications Commission will set the rules for the auction, possibly as soon as next month. Depending on that ruling, the spectrum could be used for voice services for cellular carriers, new frequencies for emergency responders, or a commercial high-speed broadband multimedia network.

docs.lead_paragraph: A group of large technology companies, universities and professional associations are creating a new organization to support and promote research into ways that technology can increase productivity and innovation in the economy's service sector. The creation of the organization, the Service Research and Innovation Initiative, will be officially announced today. It represents the latest step by technology companies and some universities to promote an emerging field that is being called ''service science.''

headline.main: New Effort to Tap Technology To Aid the Service Economy

docs.abstract: Group of large technology companies, universities and professional associations are creating new organization called Service Research and Innovative Initiative to support and promote research into ways that technology can increase productivity and innovation in economy's service sector; early academic programs are blending of computing, social sciences, engineering and management; aim of service science is to try to improve productivity and accelerate development of new offerings in services, which account for about 80 percent of US economy and similarly large shares of other Western economies; IBM and Oracle are founding corporate members of institute; other company members of organization's advisory board include Accenture, Cisco, Computer Sciences, EMC, Hewlett-Packard, Microsoft and Xerox; initiative is backed by Technology Professional Services Association and Support Professionals Association; researchers from several universities are also members, including University of California, Los Angeles, Wharton School at University of Pennsylvania, and Arizona State University; European Commission and Germany's Fraunhofer Institute are also members of advisory committee; director of group is Thomas W Pridham (M)
docs.snippet: The creation of the Service Research and Innovation Initiative represents the latest step to promote an emerging field called “service science.”

docs.lead_paragraph: NOT WORTH THE EFFORT -- Wal-Mart may be scaling back its efforts to open its first store in New York City. The chief executive of Wal-Mart, H. Lee Scott Jr., said that trying to conduct business in New York was so expensive -- and exasperating -- that ''I don't think it's worth the effort.'' [Page C1.] BURGER KING'S HUMANE POLICY -- Burger King said that it would begin buying eggs and pork from suppliers that did not confine their animals in cages and crates. Animal welfare advocates called it a ''historic advance.'' [C1.] URANIUM RUSH -- Convoluted economics and intense speculation has pushed up the price of uranium to levels not seen since the heyday of the industry in the mid-1970s. [C1.] THE VALUE OF STENTS -- At a cardiology conference, the buzz was about a new study that found little value in giving stents to most heart patients, as long as they received the right medicines. Do stents have a future? It depends on whom you ask. Market Place. [C5.] U.A.W. LEADER TALKS TOUGH -- The head of the United Automobile Workers, who has been criticized by some union members for being too willing to accept wage and benefit cuts, made clear that workers were done making sacrifices. [C3.] URGING ACTION ON SUBPRIME LOANS -- Two top regulators testified before Congress on subprime mortgages. The chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Sheila C. Bair, said that Congress should set a standard to protect borrowers against predatory lenders. And Christopher Cox, above, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said the commission had set up a 25-member enforcement unit to investigate possible fraud involving subprime mortgage lenders. [C2.] SEEKING BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION -- New Century Financial, the troubled subprime mortgage company, could file for bankruptcy protection as early as the end of this week, people briefed on the company's plans said. [C2.] HOME BUILDER'S PROFIT FALLS -- The Lennar Corporation, one of the nation's largest home builders, said that its quarterly profit fell 73 percent on continued softness in the housing market, made worse by problems with subprime lenders. [C2.] MERCK IS CLEARED IN VIOXX CASE -- Jurors in an Illinois state court sided with Merck & Company, the maker of the painkiller Vioxx, over claims that its drug was responsible for the death in 2003 of a 52-year-old woman. [C7.] CONSUMER CONFIDENCE TAKES A HIT -- Rising gasoline prices and stock market turbulence undermined consumer confidence in March, a widely watched index showed. The Conference Board said that its consumer confidence index fell to 107.2, from the revised 111.2 in February. Analysts had expected a reading of 109. [C7.] ROSNEFT BUYS YUKOS ASSETS -- Rosneft, the Russian state oil company, won an auction for assets of the bankrupt company Yukos, further tightening the Kremlin's control of energy industries in Russia. [C3.] SIEMENS EXECUTIVE ARRESTED -- German prosecutors arrested one of the top-ranking executives at Siemens in an investigation into suspected bribery. The executive was detained as prosecutors searched company offices in Munich, where Siemens is based, and two other German cities. [C3.] RAISES FOR EUROPEAN BANK CHIEFS -- Deutsche Bank and the Credit Suisse Group, two of Europe's biggest banks, rewarded their top executives with bigger paychecks last year, but their compensation still trailed that of their American counterparts. [C10.] XBOX 360, SPECIAL EDITION -- Microsoft is bringing out a new version of the Xbox 360 game machine that has a bigger hard drive, better high-definition video support and a stylish black finish, not an insignificant feature in a world where looking cool ranks high. [C5.] THE FUTURE OF SERVICES -- A group of technology companies, universities and professional associations are seeking to promote research into ways to increase productivity in the economy's service sector, which accounts for about 80 percent of the United States economy. [C5.] PARODY THEN; NOW FOR REAL -- The magazine called Heeb, a quarterly aimed at young, urban Jews, ran parody ads when it was introduced in 2002. The ads became so popular the magazine now creates real ads for real customers. Advertising. [C6.] REVIEW OF POTENTIAL CONFLICTS -- The publisher of The Los Angeles Times said the paper's readers' representative would review past editorial decisions to determine whether content had been improperly influenced by personal or professional connections. [C6.] UNIVISION TO PAY $24 MILLION FINE -- The Federal Communications Commission approved a buyout of Univision Communications after the company agreed to pay a record $24 million fine and improve the quality of its children's programming. [C6.] BUSINESS ALONG THE BORDER -- Juárez, Mexico, has become one of North America's fastest-growing markets for commercial real estate, as manufacturers build assembly plants for products like computers, appliances and medical devices. Across the Rio Grande, El Paso benefits from the growth. [C8.]

docs.lead_paragraph: With its accounting under scrutiny by federal regulators and prosecutors, Dell said yesterday that ''evidence of misconduct'' had been uncovered in an internal investigation of its financial practices over several years. Dell said its board's audit committee had ''identified a number of accounting errors, evidence of misconduct, and deficiencies in the financial control environment.'' The committee has been examining accounting and financial problems that the company previously said involved accruals, reserves and other balance-sheet items.

headline.main: Dell Reports It Has Found 'Misconduct'

docs.lead_paragraph: The Drawing Center Names a Director After a year's search the Drawing Center has appointed an executive director: Brett Littman, who has been deputy director of the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens, for nearly four years. Mr. Littman, who will begin his new job on May 7, has a lot to juggle as he tries to revitalize an institution that many in the art world say has seemed rudderless for several years, and perhaps to move the center from SoHo to Burling Slip, at John Street, in Lower Manhattan.

docs.lead_paragraph: For 133 years the School Sisters of Notre Dame have lived here in a thick forest just up the hill from the Tangipahoa River. In a modest but stately compound called St. Mary of the Pines, 52 retired members of this Roman Catholic order spend much of their time as the order's members have since the 19th century. They read and garden, fish and sew. They pray five times a day. But many also have a new hobby, one they credit for keeping their hands steady and minds sharp. They play video games. Every day residents go to the seven-terminal ''Computer Cove'' to click furiously on colorful, nonviolent, relatively simple games like Bejeweled, Bookworm and Chuzzle.

headline.main: Another World Conquered by Video Games: Retirees

docs.abstract: Large and growing number of baby boomers and their parents, especially women, play video games; older people, anxious about mental cost of aging, turn to easy to play 'casual' games that rely on quick thinking to stimulate brain activity; older users not only play video games more often than younger counterparts but also spend more time playing per session; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Older Americans are increasingly turning to video games for recreation.

docs.lead_paragraph: Outsourcing is breaking out of the back office. For years, most service industry jobs that were moved to countries like India were considered relatively low-skill tasks like answering customer inquiries. But that has been changing in recent years, and increasingly the jobs of Western white-collar elites in fields as diverse as investment banking, aircraft engineering and pharmaceutical research have begun flowing to India and a few other developing countries.

headline.main: India's Edge Goes Beyond Outsourcing

docs.abstract: Jobs of Western white-collar elites in fields as diverse as investment banking, aircraft engineering and pharmaceutical research have begun flowing to India and few other developing countries; Boeing and Airbus employ hundreds of Indians in challenging tasks like writing software for next-generation cockpits and building systems to prevent airborne collisions; investment banks like Morgan Stanley are hiring Indians to analyze American stocks, jobs that commonly pay six-figure salaries on Wall Street; with multinationals employing tens of thousands of Indians, some are beginning to treat country like second headquarters, sending senior executives with global responsibilities to work there; Cisco Systems has decided that 20 percent of its top talent should be in India within five years; global consulting giant Accenture has its worldwide head of business processing outsourcing in Bangladesh; it expects to have more employees in India than in US by December; at forefront of outsourcing business is Infosys Technologies, Indian company that has pursued strategy of reinvesting profits from low-skilled work into vast upgrading of skills to prove itself to Western companies; Infosys devotes $65 of every $1,000 in revenue to training; graph; photos (L)
docs.snippet: The outsourcing of jobs to countries like India has increasingly included the jobs of Western white-collar elites.

In the past, Norton suites have taken knocks for hogging system resources and slowing the computer, but Symantec says it has reworked the code for Norton 360.

docs.lead_paragraph: Technorati is known for its software that searches and indexes thousands of blogs. So the company is presumably quite aware of the buzz making the rounds on the Net, in which bloggers are speculating that Technorati is positioning itself for a sale. Technorati has denied those rumors, but the denials may only be fanning the flames. After Michael Arrington of TechCrunch (the blog that broke the news that Google might buy YouTube) wrote about the situation, he appended his post with this update quoting Technorati's chief executive:

docs.lead_paragraph: The federal Citizenship and Immigration Services reached its 2008 limit for skilled-worker visa petitions in a single day and says it will not accept any more, to the dismay of technology companies that rely on the visas to hire foreign employees. The agency began accepting petitions Monday for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1 and said it received about 150,000 applications by midafternoon.

headline.main: Quota Quickly Filled on Visas For High-Tech Guest Workers

docs.abstract: US Citizenship and Immigration Service reaches its 2008 limit for skilled-worker visa petitions in single day and says it will not accept any more, to dismay of technology companies that rely on visas to hire foreign employees; agency began accepting petitions April 2 for fiscal year starting Oct 1; says it received about 150,00 applications by mid-afternoon; temporary H-1B visas are for foreign workers with high-technology skills or in specialty occupations (M)
docs.snippet: To the chagrin of tech firms, the federal government said it will not accept any more visa petitions for skilled workers for 2008.

The videos have been stored in my PC, which is equipped with a recordable CD drive. A. If your computer does not have a drive that can record DVDs, you can probably burn your digital camera's clips to a video compact disc, also known as a VCD.

docs.lead_paragraph: Employees at a Wal-Mart near Saratoga, Fla., have started an aerobics class twice a week in their break room. Wal-Mart workers in Denver are reimbursed for taking public transportation to and from work. And the staff at a Sam's Club in Indianapolis now takes a daily walk around the perimeter of the store. The chain that promises ''always low prices'' seems to be adding the mantra of nonstop self-improvement.

headline.main: At Wal-Mart, Lessons in Self-Help; A New Program to Offer White-Collar Perks To Chain's Workers

docs.abstract: Wal-Mart Stores in last year has quietly introduced ambitious program in US--in equal parts self-help class, corporate retreat and tent revival--that tries to turn its 1.3 million workers into model for its 200 million customers on issues ranging from personal health to environment; program, to be announced, tests assumption, if not conventional wisdom, that environmentalism and fitness are luxuries of well-off, inaccessible to vast number of nation's working class because of hectic schedules, stretched budgets and bad habits; it thrusts Wal-Mart far deeper into workers' personal lives than company has ever reached before; specific programs detailed; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Wal-Mart has quietly introduced an ambitious self-help project to make its workers more productive.

docs.lead_paragraph: At 17, Charles Simonyi slipped out of Soviet-controlled Hungary to seek freedom. At 33, he slipped away from the safety of a large corporation, Xerox, in search of fortune at a young start-up named Microsoft. And today, at 58, that fortune is allowing him to slip the surly bonds of Earth, at least for a couple of weeks, to visit the International Space Station.

headline.main: On the Launching Pad: A $20 Million Childhood Dream

docs.abstract: Charles Simonyi, software pioneer, has paid estimated $20 million to visit International Space Station in Soyuz spacecraft; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Charles Simonyi, a software pioneer who led the teams that gave the world Microsoft Word and Excel, is the fifth so-called space tourist.

docs.lead_paragraph: During tough budget times in 1990, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. terminated the state's highway sound barrier program. Since then -- despite a significant increase in congestion -- no barriers have been built along Connecticut's busiest byways, except for a handful in areas that qualified for federal aid by expanding capacity. Some residents, particularly those living near Interstate 95, have long clamored for new sound barriers. Several years ago, Debra Kandrak, a Westport real estate agent whose home is 200 yards from the turnpike, founded an ad hoc committee called Got Noise? The group hired a firm to conduct a professional sound test and gathered more than 1,000 signatures on a petition sent to state and local officials.

headline.main: Turning Roar of the Road Into a Whisper

docs.abstract: Connecticut Senate Transportation Committee has approved bill requiring State Department of Transportation to rank sound barrier needs based on proximity to residential areas and results of scientific decibel tests; securing appropriations to actually build sound barriers beside busy highways may prove difficult; photo (M)

The service, called AOL Search Marketplace, was contemplated as part of a December 2005 deal between the companies in which Google paid $1 billion for a 5 percent stake in AOL, a unit of Time Warner.

docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft planned to announce today that it will make its Windows Live Messenger service available on its Xbox 360 game consoles, bringing instant messaging from the computer to the television. The move was meant to help Microsoft stay ahead of Sony, its chief rival in the electronic games business, in delivering the richest online experience for game players. It is also an element of Microsoft's overall strategy to connect people across PCs, televisions and mobile devices like cellphones.

headline.main: Microsoft Brings Instant Chat To TV Screen, Through Games

docs.abstract: Microsoft plans to make Windows Live Messenger service available on Xbox 360 game consoles; will allow instant message chatting on system in hopes of competing with chief rival Sony and its successful PlayStation systems; more than 200 million people use service to chat with friends, family members and colleagues through computers; Xbox Live members connect through Internet connection to allow interactive game play (M)
docs.snippet: The Windows Live Messenger will be available on the Xbox 360, bringing instant messaging from the computer to the television.

docs.lead_paragraph: In some sense, the iconic photograph of Rosa Parks recreating her quiet act of rebellion on a bus in Montgomery, Ala., belongs to every American. But as a practical matter, it belongs to Bill Gates. Anyone wanting to use that image in a book or on a Web site must first license it from Corbis, a corporation founded and owned by Mr. Gates, who is better known for starting Microsoft. The photo is among the 11 million prints and negatives in the legendary Bettmann archive, which Corbis bought in 1995.

headline.main: A Photo Trove, a Mounting Challenge; Low-Price Online Rivals Put Pressure on Corbis, Home Of Many Famous Images

docs.abstract: Corbis, corporation founded and owned by Bill Gates, is shuffling its top executives as it takes on new challenges, building up business in rights management and plotting its response to rise of low-cost online photo services that threaten to undermine its lucrative stock photo sales; plans to announce that president Gary Shenk is being made chief executive as well; departing chief executive Steve Davis will continue as senior adviser after 10 years of running company; move into rights clearance, which involves sorting out questions of who owns what material and how much they should be paid for its use, is departure from original vision of company; Corbis represents or owns rights to more than 100 million images; archival photos bring in about half of Corbis's sales, but company also has stable of professional photographers who generate stock photos for advertising and media clients; photos (L)
docs.snippet: The new chief executive for Corbis is expected to respond to the rise of low-cost online rivals that threaten to undermine its sales.

multimedia.credit: Corbis is responding to the rise of low-cost online rivals that threaten to undermine its photo sales.
multimedia.caption: Shoring Up an Archive

docs.lead_paragraph: VYING FOR RADIO SPECTRUM -- Some of Silicon Valley's most powerful venture capitalists and technology investors have joined an investment group that is preparing to challenge cellphone carriers and cable and satellite companies for valuable radio spectrum that will be freed when television broadcasters convert to digital signals. [Page C1.] THE FUTURE OF PRINTERS -- The Internet era has been good to makers of printers so far. But looking ahead, Vyomesh I. Joshi of Hewlett-Packard is concerned that if people find printing Web pages too hard and start printing less, he will have fewer coffee talks where he crows about record revenue, profit, margins and market share. [C1.] PRESS RIVALRY IN THE HAMPTONS -- This week perhaps the biggest story in The East Hampton Star involves the paper itself. The Southampton Press, the venerable paper one town over that belongs to the Louchheim family, will introduce a direct competitor, The East Hampton Press, which will come out a day earlier than The Star and will be free. (The Star costs $1.) [C1.] NO MORE SLOW BOATS FOR BOOKS -- The post office's decision to stop transporting goods via cargo ship for individual customers may not hurt big online retailers like Amazon.com, which can qualify for discounts. But thousands of smaller used- and rare-book merchants, like Rob Stuart, above, owner of Frenchboro Books in Maine, say they will suffer, because they rely on foreign demand. E-Commerce Report: Bob Tedeschi. [C6.] A MERGER COMES UNDONE -- Miles S. Nadal, the chairman and chief executive of MDC Partners, hopes to get ahead in the intensely competitive advertising industry with a contrarian strategy of almost continuous change. But following that philosophy can be fraught with risk, as was demonstrated last week with the unraveling of an acquisition and merger involving two New York agencies, which Mr. Nadal orchestrated less than two years ago. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C1.] PROXIES CLEAR AS MUD -- The Securities and Exchange Commission's new disclosure rules on executive pay were supposed to make it easier for investors to understand how top managers were being paid. But piles of new data and proxy statements that are about as easy to parse as the federal tax code have even experts scratching their heads. [C4.] A NEW XBOX 360 FEATURE -- Microsoft plans to announce today that it will make its Windows Live Messenger service available on its Xbox 360 game consoles, bringing instant messaging from the computer to the television. [C7.] FOUNDATION TAKES ON CLIMATE ISSUE -- The Doris Duke Charitable Foundation is creating a $100 million program to support research intended to encourage policies aimed at reducing the threat of global warming. [C6.] A FAKE MYSPACE PROMOTION -- The MySpace fan page with a hot pink background, tribute to Robin Sparkles, a one-hit Canadian teenage pop star from the early 1990s, was just gushing enough to be real. But it wasn't. The MySpace page was a plant, concocted by the producers of the CBS sitcom ''How I Met Your Mother,'' to play off a storyline in the show's Nov. 20 episode. [C8.] EXCLUSIVE TO THE CHICAGO TRIBUNE -- Samuel Zell, who has agreed to buy the Tribune Company, gave his first interview exclusively to The Chicago Tribune. There was no conference call with any other Tribune Company reporters who were tracking the deal, including those at The Los Angeles Times or Newsday, or in Baltimore or Hartford. [C8.] A STOCK TIP MISSES -- Jim Cramer, host of the CNBC television show ''Mad Money,'' recommended on the March 28 episode that viewers sell shares of Dendreon, a biotechnology company in Seattle. The next day, Dendreon's shares tripled when its prostate cancer vaccine was endorsed by a Food and Drug Administration panel. Some viewers are upset. [C8.] PLASTIC DOUBLES AS FUEL -- A chemistry professor has developed a ''fuel-latent plastic'' that can be used like ordinary plastic, for packaging or other purposes, but when it is waste, can easily be turned into a substitute diesel fuel. [C5.]

docs.lead_paragraph: LOW-COST video cameras, simplified software and the rise of video-sharing sites like YouTube have enabled a growing number of elderly and retired people to tell their stories. By posting what are often called video legacy projects to the Internet, retirees are finding audiences that extend far beyond their own families -- sometimes numbering in the hundreds of thousands -- and building new networks of online friends. For people whose vigor or mobility has become limited, posting videos can significantly expand their range of contacts and experiences.

headline.main: Lives on the Record and on the Web

docs.abstract: Low-cost video cameras, simplified software and rise of video-sharing sites like YouTube have enabled growing number of elderly and retired people to tell their stories; Ronni Bennett, retired former managing editor of CBSNews.com, whose popular blog Timegoesby.net, covers aging, comments; most popular Internet legacy producers is Peter Oakley, 79-year-old retired motorcycle dealer from Derbyshire, Eng, known as Geriatric1927; photo (special section, Retirement) (L)
docs.snippet: A growing number of elderly and retired people are telling their stories with Internet video.

docs.lead_paragraph: Vyomesh I. Joshi, the senior vice president in charge of Hewlett-Packard's printing division, bounded up to the stage to congratulate his employees on their performance. He was ebullient, and with good reason: revenue, profit, margins and market share were all up, he told them at a quarterly ''coffee talk'' in late February. He followed that up with a less-heartening tale. He said one of his daughters, a college student, had told him, ''I don't need a printer.'' Like many people of her generation, she lives online and finds it unnecessary or too difficult to put bits onto paper.

headline.main: H.P. Tries to Reinvent Its Masterpiece; The Push Is On to Create Printers That Love the Web

docs.abstract: Hewlett-Packard introduces strategy to make printers more Internet-friendly; senior vice president Vyomesh I Joshi hopes Web material will drive demand for printing; is planning strategic shift despite current strength in printer unit; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Hewlett-Packard is devising ways to get people to print Web pages instead of reading them on-screen.

docs.lead_paragraph: Custom Icons For Windows Vista Q. Is there a way to change folder icons in Windows Vista from something besides those annoying manila folders? A. As in previous versions of Microsoft Windows (and on the Macintosh), you can change many of the desktop and folder icons to other images. One way to change the standard Windows desktop icons (like the Recycle Bin) is by right-clicking on the desktop and selecting Personalize from the menu. On the left side of the next window, choose ''Change desktop icons'' and select the icon you want to change. Click on the Change Icon button to open a window to select a new icon from the offerings, or browse to a file or folder of icons you may have downloaded from the Web already.

docs.lead_paragraph: Google agreed to its largest acquisition yesterday, reaching a deal to purchase DoubleClick, the online advertising company, from two private equity firms for $3.1 billion in cash, almost double what it paid for YouTube last year. And perhaps just as important, the deal kept DoubleClick from the hands of Microsoft. For Google, the purchase is another step in its transformation from a search engine into an advertising powerhouse. DoubleClick, which is based in New York City, specializes in software for display advertising and has close relationships with Web publishers, advertisers and advertising agencies.

headline.main: Google Buys an Online Ad Firm for $3.1 Billion

docs.abstract: Google acquires DoubleClick, online advertising company, from private equity firms Hellman & Friedman and JMI Equity for $3.1 billion in cash; deal is another step in Google's transformation from search engine into advertising powerhouse; DoubleClick specializes in software for display advertising and has close relationships with Web publishers, advertisers and advertising agencies; Google's chief executive Eric E Schmidt says merger is part of global growth strategy for company; DoubleClick's chief executive David Rosenblatt says his company's strength lies in flashy banner ads and video advertising; deal keeps DoubleClick from Microsoft; photo (L)
docs.snippet: Google agreed to its largest acquisition Friday, reaching a deal to purchase DoubleClick for almost double what it paid for YouTube last year.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE United States has benefited immensely from its role as a magnet for the best and brightest workers from around the world, especially in innovative fields like high technology. Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, sounded precisely that theme in Senate testimony last month when asked about the visa program for skilled workers, the H-1B. Mr. Gates said that these workers are ''uniquely talented'' and highly paid -- ''taking jobs that pay over $100,000 a year'' -- and that America should ''welcome as many of those people as we can get.''

headline.main: Parsing the Truths About Visas for Tech Workers

docs.abstract: Steve Lohr Economic View column on truths about how H-1B visa program--magnet for best and brightest foreign high-tech workers--works these days; analysis by Ronil Hira, assistant professor at Rochester Institute of Technology, finds that median salary is about $50,000 and that program has become vehicle for accelerating pace of offshore outsourcing of computer work, mostly to India; photos; chart (M)
docs.snippet: Requesting the coveted H-1B visa, from India to Silicon Valley.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nicholas Fodor is about to dive into the patent wars that have tangled up the business of wireless e-mail. But his weapon of choice is not a lawsuit. It is a new e-mail service he is developing using the knowledge gained from years of experience with e-mail software. Mr. Fodor, 43, a French computer programmer, said that in the early 1990s he worked on ''push'' e-mail services that predated the filing of important patents in this area.

docs.lead_paragraph: THOSE of us hurrying to finish our taxes by tomorrow's deadline will probably, at some point, succumb to thoughts of the I.R.S. as an all-powerful bully. But the truth is, the government is not always a match for the tax advisors of wealthy people, so a lot of taxes will go unpaid at the top of the income scale. Lawyers who represent high-income taxpayers earn more than 10 times what senior government lawyers do -- an obvious disadvantage for the I.R.S., the Departments of Justice and Treasury, and for Capitol Hill in attracting and retaining top talent. The lawyers who write our tax rules are overworked and sometimes inexperienced, so they leave loopholes that are exploited by more experienced private lawyers. When the government challenges these aggressive strategies, it loses some cases that it should win, setting precedents that taxpayers then invoke to justify other aggressive strategies.

headline.main: A Few Good Lawyers

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by David M Schizer, law school dean, says many taxes will go unpaid at top of income scale; says lawyers working for government who write tax rules are overworked, sometimes inexperienced, and they leave loopholes that are exploited by private lawyers who are more experienced and much higher paid; says that is why government should substantially increase government salaries and staffing levels at Internal Revenue Service; says tax system can be only as strong as people who run it (M)
docs.snippet: The tax system can be only as strong as the people who run it, so the government has to recruit and retain the most promising talent.

The conference, the Intel Developer Forum, is held three times a year, and its convening in China underscores the growing significance of the Chinese market in the computer industry. Last month, Intel announced that it would build its first chip-making factory in China.

docs.lead_paragraph: FIRST there were boutique hotels -- small, private, luxurious and impressive. They were expensive, but that was not an issue for the people frequenting them. Now they are settings for boutique business meetings, where executives are cosseted, achievers are rewarded and group identity encouraged. These hotels are also meant for no more than a few dozen people, often those doing the most important work.

docs.lead_paragraph: I.B.M. reported solid gains in quarterly profit and modest growth in revenue yesterday, as the company's strategic shift toward higher-margin software and services makes gradual progress. The largest information technology services company, International Business Machines is also a major global supplier of software and hardware to corporations. So its results are closely watched as a barometer of corporate spending on technology.

headline.main: I.B.M. Profit Is Up, Despite Slow U.S. Sales
