docs.snippet: The company’s strategic shift toward higher-margin software and services is making gradual progress.

docs.lead_paragraph: HIDDEN LOSERS IN HOUSING SLUMP -- Among the lesser-known losers in the downturn in new home construction are immigrant workers -- most of them illegal -- who have ridden the building boom and now find jobs few and far between. [Page A1.] QUITE A TAX SHELTER -- Because of some structural differences in hedge funds, some managers of the lightly regulated private pools of money have discovered a way to avoid paying taxes on their huge fees for up to 10 years. [A1.] FOR SAFE ROAD TRAVEL ABROAD -- Rochelle Sobel founded the Association for Safe International Road Travel after her son died in a bus crash in Turkey two weeks before he was to graduate from medical school. ''It is important to not only know the laws, but the road culture before you go,'' she said. Traffic accidents are the leading cause of nonnatural death for Americans overseas, according to the State Department. [C7.] SALLIE MAE SOLD TO PRIVATE FIRMS -- Sallie Mae agreed to be sold for $25 billion to two private equity investors amid calls in Washington to cut federal subsidies for student loans. The deal has the potential not only to change Sallie Mae but also to shake up the entire lending industry. [C1.] HOME DEPOT'S GREEN LABEL -- Home Depot, the second-largest retailer in the United States, is introducing the largest green-labeling program -- for 3,000 products -- in retailing today in a move that could persuade its rivals to speed up their own plans. [C1.] TROUBLES FOR AMGEN -- Setbacks at Amgen, some unexpected and some perhaps self-inflicted, are posing new challenges in the company's previously charmed 27-year history. [C1.] A NEW SOURCE OF ETHANOL -- Because of the great worldwide demand for corn, an alternative method for producing ethanol -- using the cellulose waste from sugar cane -- has been sought by researchers, venture capitalists and government officials as a way to help end America's dependency on foreign oil. A new plant under construction in Louisiana could help in that effort. [C1.] AND DIESEL FUEL FROM WHAT? -- Tyson Foods and ConocoPhillips are forming an alliance to produce and market diesel fuel made from pork, poultry and beef fat. [C5.] A BANK DEAL IS THREATENED -- A possible bidding war has sent shares of the big Dutch bank ABN Amro soaring, which is threatening the company's takeover by its preferred suitor, Barclays. ABN Amro has also rejected an unusual takeover overture from a group of three European banks. [C1.] JUSTICES HEAR WORK-RULE CASE -- In 1975, the Labor Department exempted home care aides from federal minimum wage and overtime protections. Lawyers representing an aide from New York argued before the Supreme Court to get that regulation changed. [B2.] CLOUD OVER GUIDANT IS LIFTED -- The Food and Drug Administration erased the cloud it cast in a warning letter sent to the Guidant Corporation in December 2005, a change that should make it easier for its parent, Boston Scientific, to introduce improvements in the unit's heart-regulating implants. [C3.] WHAT WAS THAT DOMAIN NAME? -- The House is to vote on legislation that clarifies the law barring for-profit companies from using names that sound like official government agencies -- especially ones that use the letters I, R and S in a row. [C3.] AT&T ENDS BID FOR TELECOM ITALIA -- AT&T has withdrawn its offer to buy a stake in the company that controls Telecom Italia, -- perhaps dissuaded by intense political pressure in Italy against a sale to a foreign company. [C3.] YAHOO'S NEWSPAPER DEAL -- Yahoo announced a broad deal with publishers representing 264 newspapers to sell national advertising across their Web sites. [C2.] RETAIL SALES UP SLIGHTLY IN MARCH -- Retail sales rose a bit more than expected in March, but adjusted February sales were much higher than first estimated, the Commerce Department has said. [C4.] A GOOD SIGN FOR CITIGROUP? -- Citigroup's first-quarter earnings declined 11 percent because of a big charge for its recently announced corporate revamping. But the results showed progress in its expense management and strength in investment banking, and its shares rose 2.6 percent, which come at a critical time for Citigroup's chief executive. [C3.] WHAT FEMALE TRAVELERS WANT -- American Airlines has tried to tap into the female market with innovations like lie-flat business-class seats on its long-haul flights. docs.lead_paragraph: BUYING a new computer is a lot like buying or renting a new home. First you have to pick it out and pay for it, and then you have to move your stuff. And as if PC moving day weren't hard enough, most people now faced with this task have to migrate from an older version of Windows to the new Windows Vista, which typically stores user files in different folders from previous versions. Fortunately, there are a number of tools to copy folders and files from one machine to another. The Windows Easy File Transfer program that comes with Vista can help migrate program settings while Laplink's PCMover can migrate settings and try to move your software.

headline.main: Moving Day for That Vista Machine

docs.snippet: Transferring files is one thing, but software is another matter altogether.

The program, which is being announced in Beijing today by the Microsoft chairman, Bill Gates, represents an ambitious expansion of efforts to introduce products to those who have lacked access to personal computers, especially in developing nations.

headline.main: Software By Microsoft Is Nearly Free For the Needy

docs.lead_paragraph: Closing A Stubborn Folder Q. When I turn on my Windows XP computer, the folder C:windowssystem32 opens automatically every time. Why is this and how do I stop it? A. If you find the System32 folder window opening all by itself each time you start up, it may be because a leftover piece of an uninstalled program is causing problems in the Windows Registry or with your computer's start-up process. (The Registry is the database of software and hardware information Windows relies upon to function properly.) Microsoft has an article about how to fix the problem at support.microsoft.com/kb/170086. This solution, which is somewhat technical, involves editing your computer's Registry file and deleting incomplete entries -- like quotation marks on a line by themselves instead of file path information in the Data column of the Registry Editor window.

docs.lead_paragraph: Searching the Web on a mobile phone has been a lot like getting online via dial-up modem circa 1995: slow, tedious and not terribly useful. Typing on tiny buttons, squinting at a list of links and clicking through to a page that won't display properly is enough to test anyone's patience. But that is beginning to change. Google, Microsoft and Yahoo have all trained their sights on cellphones, which they see as the next great battleground in the Internet search wars. They have thrown tens of millions of dollars and armies of programmers at the problem, seeking to develop tools that people on the move can actually use.

headline.main: Big Money in Little Screens; Next Gold Mine: Web Searching By Cellphone

docs.snippet: Google, Microsoft and Yahoo have trained their sights on cellphones as the next great battleground in the Internet search wars.

docs.lead_paragraph: For much of this year, the buzz around Google has been all about the flurry of new initiatives at the No. 1 Internet search company, from its YouTube video sharing site, to its new software for office workers, to its forays into television, radio and newspaper advertising. On Thursday, Google executives sought to change the focus.

headline.main: Google Profit Soars 69% For Quarter

docs.lead_paragraph: An audit of last November's general election in the Cleveland area has found that hundreds of votes were lost, that others were recorded twice and that software used to count the ballots was vulnerable to data problems. In a state that was pivotal to President Bush's election and re-election, Cuyahoga County, which includes Cleveland, has seen more than its share of recent election troubles. Lines at polls there were hours long in the 2004 general election. And in the primaries last May, the county's first experience with electronic voting, poll workers were absent or poorly trained, computer cards on which votes had been recorded were lost, and one polling place opened hours late.

headline.main: Audit Finds Many Faults In Cleveland's '06 Voting

AMR is the first major United States airline to report first-quarter results. Its profit may set the tone for the industry, which endured several weather-related cancellations in the first three months of the year. Their new services answer urgent questions like: Where is the best local pizzeria? [C1.] CHINA KEEPS GROWING -- China's economy continues to accelerate at a blistering pace, growing 11.1 percent in the first quarter of this year from the first quarter of 2006, according to data from the National Bureau of Statistics. The surge in growth is almost certain to force Beijing to step up efforts to cool the economy. [C3.] A RUSH TO ORGANIC MILK -- Dairy farmers are hurrying to convert to organic milk production before new, more stringent federal regulations take effect, prompting predictions of a serious oversupply. Amgen's stock rose 4 percent. [C7.] STRONG SALES FOR DRUG MAKERS -- Merck, Schering-Plough and Wyeth all rode strong drug sales to quarterly profits that topped Wall Street expectations, adding to the wave of good news for investors in major pharmaceutical companies. [C2.] PROFIT IS NOT THE FULL PICTURE -- Continental Airlines and Southwest Airlines posted first-quarter profits on higher fares, but the results showed early signs that domestic air fares are under pressure. [C2.] NOKIA'S EARNINGS DROP 7% -- Nokia, the world's largest mobile phone maker, said that its first-quarter earnings dropped nearly 7 percent as expanding sales of low-end models in emerging markets pushed down its average selling price. docs.lead_paragraph: FOR all our dependence on computer software, the truth is, it isn't very safe. Recent data breaches involving tens of millions of confidential company files have made this all too clear. Why is software potentially so dangerous to the health of a business? There are scores of reasons. The big one is that software systems are so complex that it is next to impossible to find all the holes.

headline.main: To Find the Danger, This Software Poses as the Bad Guys

docs.lead_paragraph: FEW people get behind the wheel alone anymore. Many drivers wouldn't dare pull away from the curb without their cellphone, iPod or P.D.A. -- mobile devices essential to life on the move, though not necessarily designed for use in cars. To make the devices better, less distracting driving companions, more carmakers and electronics companies are using Blue-tooth technology, which wirelessly connects phones to a headset or to the car's sound system. Bluetooth is becoming the wireless standard in vehicles, and it has ambitions far beyond hands-free cellphone use.

docs.lead_paragraph: On June 25, 1980 (a date he would remember), a good-natured Filipino pool-maintenance man gathered his wife and five children for an upsetting ride to the Manila airport. At 36, Emmet Comodas had lived a hard life without growing hardened, which was a mixed blessing given the indignities of his poverty. Orphaned at 8, raised on the Manila streets where he hawked cigarettes, he had hustled a job at a government sports complex and held it for nearly two decades. On the spectrum of Filipino poverty, that alone marked him as a man of modest fortune. But a monthly salary of $50 did not keep his family fed.

Instead, from a less ostentatious corner in the basement, he selected a $40 game that would play more than reasonably well on his three-year-old Dell personal computer. The game is Civilization IV, part of a series of strategy games in which a player, like a god, develops a stone-age culture into a modern one.

docs.lead_paragraph: Far from being the cruelest month, April has turned out to be one of the most profitable in recent memory for investors in the stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average, the widely followed index of 30 large companies, closed above the 13,000 mark yesterday for the first time and is up 6 percent for the month, its best performance in a single month since December 2003.

headline.main: Dow Surge Puts 13,000 In the Past

docs.abstract: Dow Jones Industrial average closes above 13,000 mark for first time; is up 6 percent for month, its best performance in single months since December 2003; index rises 135.95 points, or 1.05 percent, to 13,089.89; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index jumps 15.01 points, or 1 percent, to 1,495.42; graphs (M)
docs.snippet: The rally has defied skeptics who thought stocks were due for a harder slog as the economy slows.

docs.lead_paragraph: Eli Broad and Bill Gates, two of the most important philanthropists in American public education, have pumped more than $2 billion into improving schools. But now, dissatisfied with the pace of change, they are joining forces for a $60 million foray into politics in an effort to vault education high onto the agenda of the 2008 presidential race. Experts on campaign spending said the project would rank as one of the most expensive single-issue initiatives ever in a presidential race, dwarfing, for example, the $22.4 million that the Swift Vets and P.O.W.s for Truth group spent against Senator John Kerry in 2004, and the $7.8 million spent on advocacy that year by AARP, the lobby for older Americans.

headline.main: Billionaires Start $60 Million Schools Effort

docs.abstract: Bill Gates and Eli Broad, two of most important philanthropists in US public education, join forces and will spend $60 million in effort to vault education high onto agenda of 2008 presidential race; project, called Strong American Schools, will be one of most expensive single-issue initiatives ever in presidential race, although it will not endorse candidates (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft reported quarterly sales and profits that surpassed Wall Street's expectations yesterday, suggesting that early sales of its new Windows Vista operating system were off to a solid start. The company, which is the world's largest software maker, also delivered an outlook for its 2008 fiscal year, which begins in July, in the upper range of analysts' projections. Microsoft said that revenue in fiscal 2008 should reach $56.5 billion to $57.5 billion, and earnings were expected to be $1.68 to $1.72 a share.

headline.main: Strong Quarter at Microsoft, and an Upbeat '08 Outlook, Bring Wall St. a Sigh of Relief

docs.snippet: Microsoft’s results suggested that early sales of its new Windows Vista operating system were off to a solid start.

docs.lead_paragraph: GOOGLE'S $3.1 billion deal for the online advertising firm DoubleClick could put the company at odds with itself. Internal conflicts often happen in finance, when investment banks find themselves advising both sides in a merger. And it happens in agribusiness, energy and other industries where giant companies with fingers in many pies are both buyers and sellers of the same commodity. But it is particularly common in technology and media.

headline.main: The Pangs of Two Becoming One

docs.lead_paragraph: FORD SEES A FUTURE -- Ford Motor Company executives said that a smaller loss in the first quarter was proof that their corporate overhaul was working. [Page C1.] LOOKING FOR A BIG HIT -- Perella Weinberg Partners may be just a year and a half old as an investment bank, but can it deliver the headline-grabbing, blockbuster mergers that made a name for its founder, Joseph R. Perella? [C1.] SOLD ON EBAY, SHIPPED VIA AMAZON -- Amazon.com is expanding a program that allows independent sellers -- even vendors who sell through Amazon's e-commerce rival, eBay -- to use its network of distribution centers to store and ship their products. [C1.] A NEW KIND OF BUYOUT -- An $8 billion bid by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Goldman Sachs for Harman International Industries, the maker of JBL speakers, has a potentially groundbreaking twist: The buyers have offered Harman shareholders a chance to retain a stake in the company, and share in any profit made if the company is later sold or taken public again. [C1.] STRONG QUARTER FOR MICROSOFT -- Microsoft reported quarterly sales and profits that surpassed Wall Street's expectations, suggesting that early sales of its new Windows Vista operating system were off to a solid start. [C3.] RISING PROFIT AT EXXON MOBIL -- Exxon Mobil reported another surge in profits for the first quarter of the year because of stronger earnings from its refining, marketing and chemicals businesses. The results -- Exxon said they were its best ever for any first quarter -- were particularly noteworthy given the mixed earnings picture reported in recent days by other large oil companies. [C4.] BETTER CHANCES FOR TRADE BILL -- Prospects have suddenly improved for bipartisan agreement on trade legislation in Congress, thanks in part to a talk between President Bush and Representative Charles B. Rangel, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. [C3.] BRISTOL CHOOSES INTERIM CHIEF -- After an eight-month search for a new chief executive, the drug maker Bristol-Myers said it would go with the interim chief, James M. Cornelius. [C2.] PUBLIC CONCERNED OVER WARMING -- Americans in large bipartisan numbers say the heating of the earth's atmosphere is having serious effects on the environment now or will soon and think that it is necessary to take immediate steps to reduce its effects, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. [A20.] EMI'S NORTH AMERICAN UNIT -- EMI Group, the struggling British music giant, has hired the longtime industry executive Roger Ames, a former chairman of Warner Music Group, to revive its North American operation. The appointment of Mr. Ames, left, comes more than three months after a management shake-up in which EMI ousted the two senior executives overseeing its recorded music operation. [C7.] A MODEL OF CONSISTENCY, ONCE -- For 25 years, Absolut vodka ran a humorous campaign celebrating its distinctive bottle, and became renowned for the consistency of its pitches to consumers. Now the brand is changing advertising approaches for the second time in 15 months. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C3.] MORE SUSPECTED BRIBES AT SIEMENS -- A day after the chief executive of Siemens announced he would step down, the company warned that it expected to report a ''significant increase'' in the number of possible bribes identified in an internal investigation. [C7.] MYSPACE.COM HEADING TO CHINA -- Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is taking MySpace.com to China, a latecomer to China's crowded field of online social networking sites that is betting it can overcome that handicap by competing unconventionally as a start-up. [C7.] CANADIAN RULES ON EMISSIONS -- Canadian industries must cut the rate at which they produce gases linked to global warming by 18 percent over the next three years, the federal government said. [C7.] PROFIT NEWS HAS LITTLE IMPACT -- Stocks ended mixed as strong profit reports from companies like Apple Inc. and 3M failed to galvanize Wall Street. Still, a modest advance gave the Dow Jones industrial average another record close. [C9.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. The US Airways Group reported that profit edged up 2 percent in the first quarter on modest revenue growth, and repeated its forecast for a profitable year. (AP) The health insurer Aetna reported an 8 percent increase in first-quarter profits, pointing to membership growth as proof that consumer marketing applied to health insurance is working. (AP) The 3M Company, considered a bellwether for the economy, posted a far better-than-expected quarterly profit, sending its shares up. (REUTERS) Coca-Cola Enterprises reported a 6 percent decline in earnings but beat Wall Street estimates, helped by the introduction of Coke Zero in Europe and raw material costs that rose less than expected. (REUTERS) The Belo Corporation, publisher of The Dallas Morning News, reported a drop in quarterly profit and revenue because of decreasing sales of classified and other advertising. (REUTERS)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Dow Jones industrial average rose above 13,000 this week, well above the highest point it reached in 2000 before the technology stock bubble burst and the country went into a recession in 2001. At the same time, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which is the Dow's principal competition for most prominent index in the United States, has not yet made it back to its lofty 2000 peak.

headline.main: The Dow May Be at Its High, but Its Performance Is Still Lacking

docs.snippet: Only half of the stocks in the Dow are higher than in 2000, while the number of rising stocks in the S.& P. is triple the number of losers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Yahoo plans to acquire Right Media, a privately held company that runs an advertising marketplace, in part to bolster its position as a seller and broker of ads outside its own sprawling network of Web sites, the companies' chief executives said yesterday. Yahoo, which bought a 20 percent stake in Right Media last October, will pay approximately $680 million, in equal parts of stock and cash, for the remaining interest in the company, which is based in New York.

headline.main: Yahoo to Buy Ad Company in Bid to Compete With Google

docs.lead_paragraph: Four states have joined forces with Google to make information from their Web sites more directly accessible through Internet searches. Much of the public data on government Web sites -- things like school rankings, contractor and real estate licenses and information on emergency and public health services -- is easy to access through the sites themselves, but is not always readily available through Web search engines.

headline.main: Google Seeks Clearer Path to State Data

docs.abstract: Arizona, California, Utah and Virginia will work with Google to make information from their Web sites more accessible through Internet searches; will use technological standard for exposing previously hidden pages online; Google hopes to extend program to other government agencies at federal, state and local level (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A LOT of the news about the Sony Corporation over the last year has been -- as its Welsh-born chairman, Howard Stringer, might say -- rather dreary. Last summer, defective Sony laptop batteries proved liable to burst into flame, prompting an embarrassing recall. The introduction last fall of the company's PlayStation 3 game system was plagued by cost run-ups and delays. Last week, the Sony games god Ken Kutaragi retired. And the company continues to search for an answer to the iPod, in the portable media player business it once ruled.

headline.main: One Crisis After Another, but Sony Shares Keep Surging

docs.abstract: Richard Siklos column on challenges Sony Corp chairman Howard Stringer faces as he struggles to bridge cultural and operational gaps; notes Sony's shares keep surging despite its business problems; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Despite a number of challenges, Sony has outperformed the Walt Disney Company, Time Warner and Comcast over the past two years.

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH player salaries in the National Basketball Association running about $5 million, on average, the N.B.A. playoffs are putting on display employees who just happen to be the best-paid union members in the world. Though we may envy their pay, we shouldn't begrudge it: N.B.A. players are arguably the most gifted group of athletes in any professional sport. They can be pitied, too. They work for employers who have embraced digital technology with intense fervor, which gives the N.B.A.'s 450 players the distinction of being perhaps the most closely scrutinized employees in the world.

docs.lead_paragraph: A JOURNAL UNDER MURDOCH? Rupert Murdoch usually gets what he wants, but he may need some of his trademark patience to convince the board of Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, to accept his $5 billion offer to buy the company. [Page A1.] The Dow Jones board said that it would take no action on the bid by Mr. Murdoch, the chairman of News Corporation, but it did not reject the offer, leaving him some wiggle room. [C1.] A deal for Dow Jones could allow thousands of its employees to cash out their stock options for a tidy profit. [C4.] Already, some investors, perhaps acting on insider information, have made a bundle by purchasing options in recent weeks speculating that Dow Jones shares would rise. [C4.] SECRET CODE IS NOW JUST A CODE -- A throng of tech-savvy Internet users have banded together over the last two days to publish and widely distribute a secret code used by the technology and movie industries to prevent piracy of high-definition movies. [A1.] FOOD IMPORT LABELED INCORRECTLY -- A Chinese company accused of selling contaminated wheat gluten to American pet food suppliers avoided inspections partly because it did not correctly disclose its shipping contents to Chinese export authorities, according to American regulators. [C1.] CHOPPED LIVER, THINKING AHEAD -- Zingerman's, in Ann Arbor, Mich., is both a beloved local deli and $30 million enterprise with a gourmet catalog and nationwide mail-order business. Its owners attribute the growth to a rare commodity in the food business -- planning ahead. [C1.] I.R.S. CURTAILS OFFSHORE AUDITS -- The Internal Revenue Service is curtailing audits of many people who use offshore tax havens because agents fear they cannot meet a three-year deadline for finishing an examination. [C1.] DON'T SKIP THIS COMMERCIAL -- How do you create a campaign for TiVo, the digital video recording device that helps people avoid advertisements? TiVo has hired an agency known for broad humor, and it has created commercials inspired by the ''TiVo Man,'' the cartoon character with an antenna on his head. Look for movie critic Gene Shalit, above, and others sporting antennas. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C5.] VYING FOR ABN AMRO -- The fight for control of ABN Amro, the largest Dutch bank, brings head to head the chiefs of Barclays and Royal Bank of Scotland, two very different individuals. [C13.] MAKINGS OF A POSSIBLE DEAL -- The Dolan family's $10.6 billion bid to buy Cablevision Systems, the company they founded, was the result of persistence and a private meeting with the two board members who had rejected previous buyout offers from the family. [C3.] MAGNA IN TALKS WITH AUTO UNIONS -- The Canadian auto parts maker Magna International, which is considering a bid for Chrysler, is in talks with Canadian and American auto unions about adding Magna's workers to their ranks. [C13.] SHRINKING NOTEBOOKS -- Ultraportable notebook computers -- supercompact, lightweight laptops that slip into briefcases as easily as a legal pad -- have made the jump from Europe and appear to be finding favor with American tastes. [C11.] LESS ENERGY, MORE SPEED -- Scientists at I.B.M. are reporting an advance in chip making that could increase the speed of semiconductors and reduce their energy consumption. [C3.] TIME WARNER RIDES CABLE EARNINGS -- Time Warner, the world's largest media company, raised its 2007 forecast after surging cable television earnings helped first-quarter profit beat analysts' estimates. Net income declined 18 percent, and sales rose 9.2 percent. Profit was dragged down by a 27 percent decline at the film division, which failed to produce a hit to beat last year's ''Harry Potter'' DVD release. [C3.] SPRINT REPORTS QUARTERLY LOSS -- The Sprint Nextel Corporation, the wireless carrier, reported a quarterly loss, fueling concern that the company was losing market share to its rivals. [C2.] ANOTHER NEW HIGH FOR THE DOW -- Shares jumped again on Wall Street, and the Dow Jones industrials past 13,200 for the first time after a strong reading on factory orders helped spur investor optimism. [C15.] WOLFOWITZ'S CONDUCT -- The World Bank committee investigating the conduct of Paul D. Wolfowitz, the bank president, are leaning toward finding that he violated the institution's rules against conflicts of interest when he arranged a pay raise and promotion for his companion, bank officials said. [A6.] WARNINGS ON SUICIDE -- The Food and Drug Administration ordered drug makers to add warnings to antidepressant medications, saying the drugs increase the risk of suicidal behavior in some young adults. [A17.] AHOLD SELLS U.S. FOODSERVICE -- The Netherlands-based grocery store operator Royal Ahold said that it had agreed to sell the distributor U.S. Foodservice to private equity firms for $7.1 billion. [C7.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. A federal judge signed off on a $1.53 billion jury verdict in favor of Alcatel-Lucent in a digital music patent dispute against Microsoft. Judge Rudi M. Brewster of Federal District Court in San Diego concluded that Microsoft's Windows Media Player software infringed on patents owned by Lucent Technologies, an American telecommunications equipment maker acquired last year by Alcatel of France. (AP)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Kindness? Charity? Understanding? When will this hellish nightmare end?'' It's a fair question inside the cynical world created in the Sam & Max adventure game series from Telltale Games. And in Sam & Max Episode 6: Bright Side of the Moon, the two work diligently to end a nightmare of peace and tranquillity. Moon is the final episode of the first season of Sam & Max, a satirical series about an anthropomorphic dog and rabbit who bill themselves as ''freelance police.'' The series is an experiment in monthly episodic game content that, depending on its success, will either inspire a series-driven style of game design or become an interesting historical footnote.

headline.main: Let's End the Nightmare of Peace and Tranquillity

docs.lead_paragraph: There is open revolt on the Web. Sophisticated Internet users have banded together over the last two days to publish and widely distribute a secret code used by the technology and movie industries to prevent piracy of high-definition movies.

headline.main: In Web Uproar, Antipiracy Code Spreads Wildly

docs.abstract: Sophisticated Internet users have banded together to publish and widely distribute secret code used by technology and movie industries to prevent piracy of high-definition movies; distribution of code may not pose serious threat to studios, because it requires technical expertise and specialized software to use, but its relentless spread is seen as lesson in mob power on Internet and futility of censorship in digital world; uproar came in response to cease-and-desist letters from lawyers demanding that code be removed from several Web sites; legal notices instead sparked proliferation of code on Web sites, chat rooms and user-submitted news sites like Digg.com; Digg initially removed codes, but users protested and Digg decided to keep postings containing code; some say there is no realistic way to pursue legal remedy against thousands of Internet users; photo of Digg.com founder Kevin Rose (M)
docs.snippet: Sophisticated Internet users have joined up to distribute a code used to prevent piracy of high-definition movies.

docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft and Yahoo are discussing a business partnership in their effort to compete with Google, people briefed on the talks said Friday. The New York Post reported Friday that Microsoft was pursuing an acquisition of Yahoo, a prospect that sent Yahoo's shares soaring. But a person briefed on the talks as recently as Friday said they had been going on for more than a year and had focused recently on a ''creative partnership,'' not an acquisition.

headline.main: Rumors Fly On Microsoft And Yahoo

docs.abstract: Yahoo shares rise while Microsoft shares decline on rumors that two are discussing business partnership in effort to compete with Google; Microsoft officials decline to comment on speculation about acquisition of Yahoo but person briefed on discussions says one option considered is linking of advertising networks to generate additional Web traffic (M)
docs.snippet: Microsoft and Yahoo are discussing a business partnership in their effort to compete with Google.

byline.original: By JOHN MARKOFF and ANDREW ROSS SORKIN; John Markoff reported from San Francisco and Andrew Ross Sorkin from New York. Miguel Helft contributed reporting from San Francisco, and Louise Story and Steve Lohr from New York

docs.lead_paragraph: Buoyed by reports of possible mergers and acquisitions, stocks surged last week, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to another record close on Friday. Last week, Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation offered to buy Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, for $5 billion, and the Thomson Corporation of Canada made a takeover approach to the Reuters Group. In addition, there were reports on Friday of talks between Microsoft and Yahoo about a business partnership -- some said even a merger. And earlier in the week, Cablevision's board said it had accepted a buyout offer from the Dolan family, the company's founders -- subject to approval by shareholders, excluding the Dolans, officers and executives of the company.

docs.lead_paragraph: Candidates Complicate Talks on Iraq War Bill Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's proposal to repeal Congressional authorization for the war in Iraq has started a scramble among Democratic presidential candidates to stake out aggressive positions opposing the war. But such calls could complicate negotiations to reach a deal on a war spending bill. PAGE A7 Tolerating Civilian Deaths Only 40 percent of marines and 55 percent of soldiers deployed in Iraq say they would report a service member for killing or injuring an innocent Iraqi, a Pentagon report shows. PAGE A7 Scottish Party Upsets Labor The separatist Scottish National Party emerged as the biggest political grouping in Scotland, ending 50 years of dominance there by the governing Labor Party and redrawing Britain's political landscape. PAGE A3 Media Deals and Alliances Thomson Corporation has approached Reuters Group about a takeover, while a Microsoft-Yahoo partnership may be in the works. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Fleeing Haitians Lost at Sea A sailing vessel carrying scores of Haitians capsized off the Turks and Caicos Islands, in shark-infested waters. Seventeen bodies were recovered, and 63 survivors, but about 60 people were missing. PAGE A8 'Greed Is Good,' Revisited Gordon Gekko, Michael Douglas's predatory financier in the 1987 movie ''Wall Street,'' is set to return in a new film. THE ARTS, PAGE B7 The Heel Is Rising Apulia, in Italy's boot, is a place that charms rather than dazzles, with farmhouses turned into small luxury resorts, impressive Baroque churches and a cuisine worth savoring. Just don't call it the next Tuscany. TRAVEL Summer Movies A special section with Parker Posey, ''The Simpsons Movie'' and the rest of the season's offerings. ARTS & LEISURE, PART 2 T: Living The New York Times Style Magazine takes on terroir, the notion that one can taste in wine the earth in which the grapes were grown. Also: On the job with the sausage king Paul Bertolli. Where Are the Black Swans? Between American Ballet Theater and New York City Ballet, there is just one black ballerina now, a reflection of the complicated reality and persistence of racial inequality in classical dance. ARTS & LEISURE

docs.lead_paragraph: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday, carving out their fourth straight weekly gain amid a fresh round of corporate takeover news and employment figures that largely met expectations. There is speculation that Thomson, the provider of financial data, is the likely suitor for Reuters, the British news and information company.

docs.lead_paragraph: COLLABORATION can be a powerful driver of innovation when it is done thoughtfully. But thoughtfulness can be hard to achieve in a traditional corporate or academic setting, where getting the best of others -- whether by winning a sale or an argument -- tends to be rewarded. Tradition being what it is, even organizations that pine for new ideas struggle with how to change their cultures to support them. The Interactive Telecommunications Program at New York University provides a longstanding example of why they should keep trying.

headline.main: Winning Isn't Everything. Check the Periphery.

docs.abstract: Denise Caruso column on Interactive Telecomunications Program at New York University, run by Prof Red Burns since 1983; program is preparing to host its annual spring show of student work, which is open to public; program and its predecessor, Alternate Media Center, has been hothouse for innovations that use technology to connect people to one another and to rest of world in new and unpredictable ways for more than 35 years; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: You'll never be able to buy a boxed version of Microsoft's latest mobile operating system, but who needs boxes? Windows Mobile 6, a considerable upgrade to the company's operating system for smartphones and P.D.A.'s, is now available as a free download for owners of the T-Mobile Dash. Versions will soon be released for other smartphones, old and new, from multiple carriers. Windows Mobile 6 handles standard functions like contacts and calendars and, with the right software, can synchronize with Macs and PCs. The new version, however, includes many of Microsoft's latest search technologies, ensuring that high-speed data connections and the peppier processors in today's smartphones won't go to waste.

docs.lead_paragraph: FED SEES A SLOWING ECONOMY The Federal Reserve acknowledged that the economy was slowing, but offered little hint that it was ready to lower interest rates anytime soon. The central bank kept the benchmark interest rate on overnight loans at 5.25 percent -- the same level it has been for almost a year. [Page C1.] THE AIRLINE FLIES IT; HE OWNS IT Steven Udvar-Hazy owns more airplanes than any airline in the world. A billionaire three times over and one of the most powerful players in commercial aviation, he is founder and chief executive of a Los Angeles-based company that leases planes to airlines all over the world. [C1.] HBO CHIEF AGREES TO RESIGN Time Warner announced that the chairman and chief executive of its Home Box Office unit, Chris Albrecht, had agreed to resign at the company's request, three days after he was arrested and charged with assaulting a girlfriend in a Las Vegas parking lot. [C1.] QUESTIONS FOR RESPECTED BANKER David K. P. Li of Hong Kong, who is expected to be questioned by authorities about a possible insider-trading case involving shares of Dow Jones, is an aristocratic banker who combines wealth, political influence and public service. [C1.] WITNESS'S CREDIBILITY ATTACKED A defense attorney in Conrad M. Black's criminal fraud trial attacked the credibility of the chief prosecution witness, F. David Radler, by pointing out the numerous times Mr. Radler had lied before he cut a deal with federal prosecutors. [C3.] A LOSS REPORTED BY TXU The TXU Corporation said that it swung to a loss in the first quarter after revenue fell 28 percent and it took a charge to cancel coal-fired power plants, a condition of the company's pending $32 billion sale to private owners.[C2.] MAGNA CONFIRMS CHRYSLER BID The chairman of the auto parts maker Magna International confirmed that his company and Onex, a Canadian investment company, had made a bid for Chrysler. [C3.] SLOWER PROFIT GROWTH AT TOYOTA Toyota reported another year of record profit but signaled a slowdown in the current year because of weakness in North America and increased spending. Toyota said its net profit jumped about 20 percent in the fiscal year ended in March, but forecast only a 0.4 percent rise in the current year. The slowdown ''is temporary, as we are planting the seeds'' of future growth, said Toyota's president, Katsuaki Watanabe, above. [C3.] EUROPEAN NAVIGATIONAL SATELLITES The European Commission is abandoning plans to build a satellite navigation system in partnership with private industry. The commission is likely to propose the project be wholly financed by the public sector. [C2.] MICROSOFT AND CAREERBUILDER Microsoft said that it would take a small equity stake in CareerBuilder, a popular job recruitment site operated by three big media companies. The deal deepens an existing partnership in a lucrative category of online classified advertising. [C11.] PROFIT 6.2% HIGHER AT NEWS CORP. The News Corporation, which disclosed a surprise bid for Dow Jones & Company last week, reported 6.2 percent higher quarterly profit on gains at its movie studio and cable networks, including Fox News Channel. By far the largest contributor to earnings and revenue growth in the latest quarter was movie and television production, whose profit jumped 82 percent, thanks in part to home video sales of ''Borat'' and the theatrical release of ''Night at the Museum'' and other movies. [C4.] STRENGTHENING THE F.D.A. The Senate passed a bill that gives the Food and Drug Administration new power to police drug safety, order changes in drug labels, regulate advertising and restrict the use and distribution of medicines found to pose serious risks to consumers. [A1.] MONEY, DRUGS AND INFLUENCE The intersection of money and medicine -- such as payments by a drug company to a prescribing physician -- has become an especially contentious issue in psychiatry, where increasing fees paid to doctors have coincided with the growing use of a relatively new class of drugs. [A1.] BATTLE OF BRITAIN'S TABLOIDS Two free tabloids in Britain are fighting a battle on the streets of London by trying to disprove their competitor's circulation claims. Advertising. [C4.] DRUG TESTING AT WORK A growing number of employers are establishing workplace drug programs, including testing workers for drug use, as a way to prevent accidents and lost productivity caused by substance abuse. Small Business. [C6.] INTEL VS. A.M.D. The fierce rivalry between the chip makers Intel and Advanced Micro Devices is ratcheting up as both companies claim superiority in technology used for notebook computers. [C5.] MARKETS REGAIN STRIDE Wall Street wobbled, then regained its stride after the Federal Reserve told investors what they expected to hear: that inflation is still too high for comfort, but that the central bank is holding interest rates steady. [C13.] MORE TIME FOR WOLFOWITZ The World Bank board, bowing to pressure from the Bush administration, agreed to give Paul D. Wolfowitz, the bank president, slightly more time to defend himself against charges of misconduct before the board decides his future. [A8.] VERIZON CUTS TIES WITH SINGER Verizon has ended its advertising affiliation with Akon, a smooth, Senegalese-American R&B singer, whose conduct in an amateur video circulating online recently seemed to cross a line for the telecommunications company. The move by Verizon has sent a chill through the ranks of touring pop artists and agents. [E1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: TARUN ANAND, the co-founder and chief executive of the Perfect Future, a start-up near Delhi, made his fortune in the United States, but returned to India to become an entrepreneur. He wants to use Web and mobile telephone technology to reform, or at least begin to improve, the uneven condition of education in his homeland. I met Mr. Anand on a recent trip to India, where he introduced me to his company. Wearing a chartreuse cotton kurta, the traditional knee-length shirt of northern India, he arrived at my hotel and drove me through the squawking chaos of Delhi's industrial suburbs.

His add-on will replace the display ads -- which are usually papered over with blank windows -- with curator-picked artwork from contemporary artists.

headline.main: Web Fight: Blocking Ads and Adding Art

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the short history of the Internet, most online videos have been funny, fleeting clips lasting only a few minutes -- sometimes just seconds. Web sites like YouTube and MySpace are populated with bite-size videos that the youngster down the street whipped up in his spare time. And media companies like Viacom and NBC have posted abridged versions of popular shows on their Web sites. But the future of online television may lie with longer programs, the kind that merit curling up on your couch rather watching from your office chair. Most video viewing, after all, is still on television sets, and many people turn them on for hours at a time. In contrast, Nielsen Net/Ratings finds that consumers visit YouTube on average for only 11.5 minutes at a time.

headline.main: A Diet, Oddly Bland, of Continuous Images and Chat

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Internet search engine is an indispensable tool of modern life and an advertising gold mine for Google, the favorite first stop on the Web. But searching accounts for only about 5 percent of the time people spend online; the other 95 percent is spent on the wider Web, where a different advertising landscape looms. Instead of the short text ads that appear on a Google results page after a search, visitors often find display ads that are the Internet's equivalents of glossy magazine ads or television commercials. These are typically the province of brand advertisers like Cadillac and Coke.

docs.lead_paragraph: Amazon.com, the biggest online seller of CDs, is joining the movement against copy-protection software for digital music. It plans to sell songs that can be freely copied to any computer, cellphone or music player, including the iPod from Apple. The move could be another step toward the demise of the copy-protection systems that have frustrated some online music buyers and created confusion about compatibility between digital players and downloaded songs. Critics charge that the software has slowed the public embrace of legal digital downloads while failing to stop illicit copying, at a time when the music industry is desperate for ways to make up for declining CD sales.

headline.main: Amazon to Sell Music Without Copy Protection

docs.lead_paragraph: The most commonly cited culprits for the income inequality in America -- outsourcing, immigration and the gains of the super-rich -- are diversions from the main issue. Instead, the problem is largely one of (a lack of) education. The extent of outsourcing, for instance, is not yet high enough to have much effect on American wages. Even if a call center is set up in India, this helps American business expand at home. Most generally, the net flow of investment is into the United States, not away from it. It appears that more American jobs are ''in-sourced'' than outsourced.

headline.main: Why Is Income Inequality in America So Pronounced? Consider Education

docs.abstract: Tyler Cowen Economic Scene column on education as main reason for income inequality in America; cites findings by Harvard Profs Claudia Goldin and Lawrence F Katz on evolution of US educational wage differentials (M)
docs.snippet: American lower education does not prepare enough people to receive gains from American higher education.

docs.lead_paragraph: In an effort to catch up with Google's fast-growing online advertising business, the WPP Group, the advertising holding company that owns traditional ad agencies like JWT and the Grey Global Group, agreed yesterday to pay about $649 million to acquire 24/7 Real Media, an advertising network and technology company. WPP's chief executive, Martin Sorrell, who called Google a ''frenemy'' last fall, has publicly expressed concern in recent weeks about Google's plan to pay $3.1 billion to acquire DoubleClick, another online advertising company that has a strong presence in display advertising. Antitrust regulators are evaluating that purchase.

docs.lead_paragraph: Don't envy Jack Tretton. As the new chief executive of Sony Computer Entertainment America, Mr. Tretton may have the toughest job in the video game business (with the possible exception of his boss, Kazuo Hirai, who is taking over Sony's global game operation). After years of relentless hype, last November Sony introduced its flagship game machine, the PlayStation 3, with a resounding thud. The brainchild of Mr. Hirai's predecessor, the engineer Ken Kutaragi, the PlayStation 3 has been hobbled by its lackluster online service, a dearth of ''must-have'' games and, perhaps most important, its stratospheric $599 price.

docs.lead_paragraph: RODNEY MONROE, the police chief in Richmond, Va., describes himself as a lifelong cop whose expertise is in fighting street crime, not in software. His own Web browsing, he says, mostly involves checking golf scores. But shortly after he became chief in 2005, a crime analyst who had retired from the force convinced him to try some clever software. The programs cull through information that the department already collects, like ''911'' and police reports, but add new streams of data -- about neighborhood demographics and payday schedules, for example, or about weather, traffic patterns and sports events -- to try to predict where crimes might occur.

docs.lead_paragraph: Reggie Fils-Aime, president and chief operating officer of Nintendo of America, is certainly the game industry's man of the moment, at least in the United States. Mr. Fils-Aime and his crew staged a day of media events here this week amid one of the most remarkable turnabouts in fortune gamers have seen since Atari went belly up two decades ago. After placing a distant third in the last generation's console wars, behind the PlayStation 2 and Microsoft's original Xbox, Nintendo has roared back to a position approaching dominance on the strength of its two innovative machines: the hand-held Nintendo DS and the much-lauded Wii. Last month, Nintendo sold more than four times as many Wii units (360,000) as Sony sold PlayStation 3's (82,000), and many people still can't find the Wii on store shelves.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dell, in a first step toward transforming its ailing strategy of selling direct to consumers, said yesterday that it planned to offer computers at Wal-Mart Stores, starting in June. It is a tightly restrained move. The computer company will sell only two models of multimedia computers, from Dell's low-end Dimension line, though they will be available in more than 3,000 stores in the United States and Puerto Rico, Wal-Mart said. The computers will sell for less than $700. The retailer said the two models would also be available in its Sam's Club stores and outlets in Canada.

docs.lead_paragraph: On a spring Saturday, about 90 students from Stanford and as many from the University of California, Berkeley, converged on Google's corporate campus for a day of spirited team competition over mind-bending puzzles, Lego building problems and video games. It was called the Google Games, a convivial way for the mostly computer science and engineering students to renew the Stanford-Berkeley rivalry. But behind the fun was a serious corporate recruiting event that underscores a rivalry no less intense: the tug of war for talent between Google and its competitors.

headline.main: In Fierce Competition, Google Finds Novel Ways to Feed Hiring Machine

docs.lead_paragraph: A DAY OFF All banks and stock markets in the United States are closed today in observance of the Memorial Day holiday. They will reopen on Tuesday. SIGNALS ON THE ECONOMY It will be a heavy week for economic data. On Friday, the government will issue its employment report for May, as well as reports on personal income and spending for April. In addition, the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing index for May will be released along with the University of Michigan consumer sentiment index. Also on Friday, automakers will report sales for May.

docs.lead_paragraph: RECRUITING BATTLES As much of the high-tech industry is enjoying a renewed boom, the competition for top recruits in engineering and other fields is as intense as ever. Companies like Google, Microsoft and Yahoo find themselves going after the same candidates or recruiting in one another's backyards. At the same time, they are running up against a myriad of start-up companies across Silicon Valley. To lure talent, these companies have expanded their recruiting arsenal far beyond the traditional job fair to include events like technology lectures, cocktail parties, pizza parties, treasure hunts and programming contests, called ''code jams'' or ''hack days.'' [Page C1.] LOOKING FOR STARS Despite being the first and certainly the largest African-American cable channel, Black Entertainment Television has developed few of its own marketable stars and virtually no breakout programs. It relies on reruns, movies and music videos for the bulk of its lineup. The chief executive of BET, Debra L. Lee, has tried to reverse that trend, this year increasing the channel's production budget 50 percent and plunging into original programming with 16 new shows for the fall. [C1.] POLICEMAN, NOT A REPORTER David Cunningham, a prominent protester who heads the Anti-Poverty Committee in Vancouver, British Columbia, recently received a call from someone who said he was a reporter named Peter MacKay from the free daily tabloid 24 Hours Vancouver. But when Mr. Cunningham arrived outside a shopping mall for what he thought would be an interview, Peter MacKay turned out to be a plainclothes police officer who arrested him. Someone in the Vancouver Police Department thought the deception was a clever way to lure Mr. Cunningham, but the ruse provoked widespread criticism from civil rights and journalism groups. [C4.] HIGH ASPIRATIONS Though far from a household name in telecommunications, Altimo, the Russian telecommunications investment company, has aspirations of becoming a global power. But the problem it faces, some analysts say, is that at this point, Altimo has made few allies. If it is known beyond Russia at all, it is for its propensity to fight tenaciously in court and on corporate boards for its ambitions, some say. [C5.] THE MALE DIETER The face of dieting may be changing. Of the 72 million people dieting in the United States, 38 percent -- about 28 million -- are men, according to Marketdata Enterprises, a market research company. It estimates that the diet industry will be $58.7 billion this year. And NutriSystem has hired its first male spokesman, the former quarterback Dan Marino, and has started advertising in Sports Illustrated, Men's Health and ESPN magazine. [C3.] MAINSTREAM PROMOTION Mel Gibson's 2004 film ''The Passion of the Christ'' demonstrated to Hollywood just how many evangelical moviegoers there are and how much money can be made from them. Mindful of that market, Universal Pictures has teamed up with Grace Hill Media, a public relations firm that reaches out to religious groups, to publicize the mainstream film ''Evan Almighty.'' Scheduled for wide release on June 22, it stars Steve Carell as a politician who abandons Congress in order to build an ark, taking off on the story of Noah. [C3.] TALLYING GLIMPSES When the sleek yacht of the Luna Rossa team sailed away with a victory in the America's Cup semifinals, there were two vital results. The Italian crew eliminated the American team of BMW Oracle Racing with a 33-second lead. And fleeting glimpses of the flapping mainsails -- branded with logos of Telecom Italia Mobile and the broadband service Alice -- reached millions of television viewers. Those glimpses are now being counted down to the second, categorized by clear and partial visibility, tallied by major countries and then compared with the cost of traditional spot advertisements. [C2.] WEB PROPERTY DEVELOPER NameMedia, a privately held owner and developer of Web sites based in Waltham, Mass., is best seen as an online property developer, its chief executive, Kelly P. Conlin, said. Analysts suggest that NameMedia and its competitors could represent the next wave of Internet initial public offerings, while also providing a peek at a significant change in what people see when they stumble onto obscure Web properties. Bob Tedeschi, E-Commerce Report. [C5.] THE TOUCH-UP In a situation not as emotionally charged as when Time magazine darkened O.J. Simpson's mug shot on its cover a decade ago, no fewer than three magazines were reacting to claims last week that they had doctored their covers -- and one retouched celebrity even cried foul. [C4.] A PULITZER AWARD Often the writing and photography that win Pulitzer Prizes require heroic efforts. For one recipient, Jahangir Razmi , the process of receiving the award also took 27 years. In 1979, Mr. Razmi stood near executioners as they shot Kurdish prisoners in Sanandaj, Iran. One picture was picked up by the wire service United Press International. To protect Mr. Razmi, his name was never printed. But after decades of keeping silent, Mr. Razmi allowed his name to appear in a December 2006 article in The Wall Street Journal, which prompted the Pulitzer Prize Board to seek out Mr. Razmi to award him the prize in person. [C4.] VIEWER REVOLT The cancellation of the CBS series ''Jericho'' has led to a viewer revolt that has included not only the usual petition drives, but also the delivery of tons of nuts (mostly walnuts, but also peanuts and pecans) to the two responsible CBS executives. [C4.] THE PRETEEN MARKET With a faithful audience in the millions, magazines for the early teenage years are in overdrive, bolstered by last year's enthusiasm for new stars from the Disney Channel's hit ''High School Musical,'' which made household names not only of Zac Efron and Corbin Bleu, but also of Ashley Tisdale and Vanessa Anne Hudgens. [C1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission has opened a preliminary antitrust investigation into Google's planned $3.1 billion purchase of the online advertising company DoubleClick, an industry executive briefed on the agency's plans said yesterday. The inquiry began at the end of last week, after it was decided that the Federal Trade Commission instead of the Justice Department would conduct the review, said the executive, who asked not to be identified because he had not been authorized to speak. The two agencies split the duties of antitrust enforcement.

docs.lead_paragraph: THESE days, Google seems to be doing everything, everywhere. It takes pictures of your house from outer space, copies rare Sanskrit books in India, charms its way onto Madison Avenue, picks fights with Hollywood and tries to undercut Microsoft's software dominance. But at its core, Google remains a search engine. And its search pages, blue hyperlinks set against a bland, white background, have made it the most visited, most profitable and arguably the most powerful company on the Internet. Google is the homework helper, navigator and yellow pages for half a billion users, able to find the most improbable needles in the world's largest haystack of information in just the blink of an eye.

headline.main: Inside the Black Box

docs.snippet: Google’s top minds offer a peek inside the algorithm that provides search results for half a billion users.

byline.original: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN and JOHN MARKOFF

docs.lead_paragraph: TRASH MOUNTAIN The News -- Climbers from Japan and Nepal removed about 1,100 pounds of garbage from Mount Everest. Behind the News -- The world's highest mountain, at 29,028 feet, has also been called the world's highest garbage dump. Over the years, would-be summiteers have left behind tons of trash -- tents, oxygen bottles, pots, stoves and other junk, not to mention the corpses of dozens of climbers. The Japanese climber Ken Noguchi says his teams have hauled 19,800 pounds of garbage in five trips since 2000. This year, he says, ''the amount of waste left on the mountain has been drastically decreased.'' SPACE DEBRIS The News -- Two Russian cosmonauts erected protection panels on the International Space Station to shield it from space debris. Behind the News -- The cosmonauts spent about five and a half hours outside setting up the protective panels. Scientists consider space debris, which includes discarded rocket parts and small rocks, to be the biggest threat to the space station, which orbits 220 miles above Earth. NASA says about 11,000 human-created objects larger than 10 centimeters -- about 4 inches -- are in orbit, plus another 100,000 particles between a centimeter and 10 centimeters in size. CALL IN THE BULLDOZERS The News -- Officials in India said Wednesday they are seeking developers to demolish the Dharavi slum in Mumbai, India's financial and entertainment capital. Behind the News -- The slum's tin shanties and garbage-strewn alleys lie on prime land in the heart of the city. Perhaps one million people live in Dharavi, but the city counts just 56,000 families. The United Nations estimates there is 1 toilet per 1,440 people. Mumbai wants to build new housing, shopping, schools and hospitals as part of a $2.3 billion project. Residents will be offered free 225-square-foot apartments, but some say they fear they will end up with nothing. SPAMALOT NO MORE The News -- Federal authorities in Seattle arrested a man they say is one of the world's most prolific e-mail spammers. Behind the News -- Robert Alan Soloway, 27, was accused of using networks of compromised computers to send out millions of spam e-mails. Mr. Soloway advertised that he could send out 20 million e-mails over 15 days for $495, according to the federal indictment. He pleaded not guilty to charges of mail, wire and e-mail fraud and other crimes. ''He's one of the top 10 spammers in the world,'' said Tim Cranton, a Microsoft lawyer. ''He's a huge problem for our customers. This is a very good day.'' NO WHERE LEFT TO GO The News -- Tons of garbage piled up on the streets of Naples, Italy, after the only working dump in the area closed. Behind the News -- Italy's president warned of an ''ecological and health disaster'' in the country's third-largest city. The city's neighborhoods have resisted efforts to build incinerators, recycling centers and new trash sites as existing dumps filled up. One nearby town has opened its dump for 20 days to take some trash, but after that, who knows? Many residents are burning their refuse or leaving it to rot. ''This is a situation that is tied to the incapability of the political structure,'' said one politician.

docs.lead_paragraph: RECRUITERS with six-figure jobs to fill know better than to post them online and start a stampede of marginally qualified job seekers. But they also know that the Web is the easiest way to find applicants. The Web's surprising answer to the problem? Charge them to look.

headline.main: Listing Top Jobs but Charging Candidates to Seek Them

docs.abstract: Growing number of Web sites catering to companies seeking to fill high-end jobs begin charging applicants for access to advertisements; move controls stampede of marginally qualified job seekers, making process easier for employers; sites like TheLadders.com, ExecuNet and others will fill void that exists on larger online job boards such as Monster, CareerBuilder and Yahoo's HotJobs, which have been unsuccessful in higher-end market; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A growing number of niche sites devoted to high-end jobs are finding that applicants will shell out a few dollars  or a few hundred  for access to job ads.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE story of the college dropout who became the world's richest man still has the power to inspire us. It affirms our deeply engrained view that rejecting the received wisdom (do my own thing!) is a path to creativity and wealth. As Walt Whitman famously wrote 150 years ago, ''I celebrate myself, and sing myself.'' In our individualistic country, the strong, lone voice is often viewed as the animating force behind every kind of success.

headline.main: Genius and Misfit Aren't Synonyms, or Are They?

docs.snippet: In Silicon Valley, where misfits rule, rejecting the received wisdom is commonly viewed as a path to creativity and wealth.

But this year, at BookExpo America, the publishing industry's annual convention that ended yesterday, the battering ram of technology was back.

docs.lead_paragraph: JAMES D. WATSON, who helped crack the DNA code half a century ago, last week became the first person handed the full text of his own DNA on a small computer disk. But he won't be the last. Soon enough, scientists say, we will all be able to decipher our own genomes -- the six billion letters of genetic code containing the complete inventory of the traits we inherited from our parents -- for as little as $1,000.

headline.main: 6 Billion Bits of Data About Me, Me, Me!

docs.abstract: James D Watson is first person to have full text of his own DNA on small computer disk; scientists say that soon people will be able to buy copies of their own genetic code for as little as $1,000; as thousands of people decode their DNA, they will face genetic mirror whose reflection changes on almost daily basis; people may find that they carry genes that increase risk of certain disease or that they carry genes that offset risk or that they carry both; experts caution that lack of established medical authorities to interpret or filter such information could cause deep discomfort; technology is quickly outpacing social debate over how it should be handled; photo; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: A DNA code cracker got his genome. Lines form now for everyone else.

docs.lead_paragraph: A DIGITAL camera can save photos in a file format called JPEG, and sometimes in other formats like TIFF or RAW. A computer's photo software offers even more choices. While the options can seem bewildering, it pays to know something about them. Format choice can make a big difference, depending on what you want to do with your pictures. For most people, JPEG is a good format. It's universal, compatible with all digital cameras, all photo software and all commercial print services. It also makes compact files that don't hog space on a camera's memory card or take long to download.

headline.main: Wading Through Formats: JPEG, TIFF and Friends

docs.lead_paragraph: ANTI-PROFANITY RULE STRUCK DOWN A federal appeals panel struck down the government policy that allows television stations and broadcast networks to be fined if they run shows containing profanities. Network executives and officials at the Federal Communications Commission said the opinion could gut the ability of the F.C.C. to regulate any speech on television or radio. [Page A1.] CHINA'S WILD-WEST FREE MARKET Recent incidents involving Chinese manufacturers trying to cut corners with ingredients used in pet foods and toothpaste are signs of a free market that is driven by entrepreneurs who are taking advantage of a weak legal system, lax regulations and a business culture where bribery and corruption are rampant. THE WEB In the battle between Apple and Microsoft, Bertrand Serlet and Steven Sinofsky are the field generals in charge of competing efforts to ensure that the PC's basic software stays relevant in an increasingly Web-centric world. [C1.] A SELL-OFF IN CHINA China's stock market tumbled again. Stocks have fallen by a total of about 15 percent since the government announced last Wednesday that it would triple a tax on stock trades. But there has been little effect on markets outside China. [C1.] Wall Street recovered from a mostly down session, eking out a gain as investors brushed off another slide in Chinese stocks. [C9.] JACKSON HEWITT INQUIRY WIDENS Federal authorities have expanded an investigation into accusations that Jackson Hewitt Tax Service offices helped prepare fraudulent income-tax returns that allowed customers to obtain refunds illegally. The Justice Department filed lawsuits in April accusing more than 125 Jackson Hewitt offices of enabling customers to file false returns. Late last week, Jackson Hewitt disclosed that the company was the subject of an Internal Revenue Service investigation. [C2.] A MUTED DEFENSE FOR BLACK The defense portion of Conrad M. Black's criminal fraud case is expected to wrap up later this week after only a handful of witnesses, none of whom are the bold-faced figures Mr. Black was known for associating with when he built one of the world's largest newspaper companies, Hollinger International. [C3.] INVESTING IN HEALTH CARE A former health official in the Bush administration is starting a $700 million private equity fund with a mission to invest in companies trying to reduce the cost of health care. At the outset, the sole investor will be Calpers, the largest public pension fund in the United States. [C3.] FROM BEYOND THE GRAVE Dead celebrities have a way of showing up in advertising, but when the London office of Saatchi & Saatchi recently featured images of Kurt Cobain, left, and other dead rock stars in ads for Dr. Martens footwear, the agency and its client got burned. What started out as a legitimate use of the photo of Mr. Cobain went wrong because of a series of missteps and the border-hopping power of the Internet. Advertising. [C8.] WARNER MUSIC'S INTERNET DEAL Warner Music Group, has made a deal with an Internet start-up, Lala .com, that will allow anyone to listen to its music free, with the idea that doing so will drive music sales. [C8.] CHINA'S CLIMATE STRATEGY China staked out its position on global warming by releasing its first national strategy on climate change, a plan that promises to improve efficiency but rejects mandatory caps on greenhouse gas emissions. [A12.] OPPOSITION TO BIOMET DEAL At least one significant investor in Biomet plans on voting against a proposed $10.9 billion deal for the artificial joint maker, in the latest instance of shareholder dissatisfaction in the world of buyouts. [C8.] EMISSIONS-TRADING RULES Europe is moving toward making significant changes to its emissions-trading system that could force large polluters to pay for most, if not all, permits to produce climate-changing gases, European officials said. [C8.] PANEL TO ADVISE F.D.A. ON WARNINGS The Food and Drug Administration said that it would appoint a panel of outside specialists to advise the agency on how to tell the public about the risks and benefits of medicines and medical devices. [C3.] AN INVESTMENT IN PALM A private equity investment in Palm Inc. was announced, a signal that new competition that will increasingly blur the lines between telecommunications, computing and entertainment during the next several years. [C3.] ONLINE NEW SQUAWK BOX TRIAL A federal judge has scheduled a second trial for November in the case of a group of former brokers and day-trading executives accused of scheming to profit improperly from ''squawk box'' information broadcast over brokerage loudspeakers. (REUTERS) MORTGAGE ACQUISITION The Accredited Home Lenders Holding Company, a struggling subprime mortgage lender, has agreed to be acquired by a private equity firm, Lone Star Funds, for $400 million, the companies said yesterday. (REUTERS) ENRON SENTENCE The former chief operating officer of Enron's broadband Internet division, Kevin P. Hannon, was sentenced to two years in federal prison for his role in the fraud that led to the company's collapse, a court official said. (REUTERS)

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly a decade after the government began its landmark effort to break up Microsoft, the Bush administration has sharply changed course by repeatedly defending the company both in the United States and abroad against accusations of anticompetitive conduct, including the recent rejection of a complaint by Google. The retrenchment reflects a substantially different view of antitrust policy, as well as a recognition of major changes in the marketplace. The battlefront among technology companies has shifted from computer desktop software, a category that Microsoft dominates, to Internet search and Web-based software programs that allow users to bypass products made by Microsoft, the world's largest software maker.

headline.main: MICROSOFT FINDS LEGAL DEFENDER IN JUSTICE DEPT.

docs.snippet: A company the government once tried to break up has been repeatedly defended by the Bush administration against charges of anticompetitive conduct.

docs.lead_paragraph: Henning Kagermann, 59, chief executive of SAP, the big German software company, is guiding two transformations. The first is the increasing globalization of the engineering work at the company, which traditionally handled technical development at its home in Walldorf. The second is the continuing opening up of SAP's technology itself in response to the rise of the Internet and the growing popularity of Web-based computing. Both trends are affecting all large technology companies today. Yet the shifts seem particularly notable at SAP. The company is the world leader in the business applications software that corporations use to automate operations, including finance, manufacturing, human resources and managing customer relations.

headline.main: Tapping Global Talent In Software

docs.lead_paragraph: WHAT a difference 16 years makes. Last month, the technology world was abuzz over an interview in Fortune magazine in which Bradford Smith, Microsoft's general counsel, accused users and developers of various free software products of patent infringement and demanded royalties. Indeed, in recent years, Mr. Smith has argued that patents are essential to technological breakthroughs in software. Microsoft sang a very different tune in 1991. In a memo to his senior executives, Bill Gates wrote, ''If people had understood how patents would be granted when most of today's ideas were invented, and had taken out patents, the industry would be at a complete standstill today.'' Mr. Gates worried that ''some large company will patent some obvious thing'' and use the patent to ''take as much of our profits as they want.''

headline.main: A Patent Lie

docs.abstract: Timothy B Lee Op-Ed article holds that patents are bad for software industry; says nothing illustrates that better than conflict between Verizon and Vonage; notes that in 1991, Bill Gates predicted that large company would 'patent some obvious thing,' and that is exactly what Verizon has done; says two of its patents cover concept of translating phone numbers into Internet addresses; contends that it is virtually impossible to create consumer-friendly Internet telephone product without doing that; maintains that if Verizon prevails on appeal, it will probably be able to drive Vonage out of business (M)
docs.snippet: Nothing illustrates the way patents harm the software industry better than the conflict between Verizon and Vonage.

docs.lead_paragraph: Canceled flight? Change of plans? Just plain busy? Grab your smart phone or PDA and visit www.tripsync.com to reserve a car, flight or hotel using real-time information. Any portable, Web-enabled device is compatible with the service, which is free. Microsoft Outlook fans should be especially excited about TripSync, as it instantly updates the reserved travel information on each user's calendar. On July 7, the New Seven Wonders of the World are to be announced in Lisbon. The selections are being made by voters who signed on to www.new7wonders.com; among the nominees are Chichén-Itzá in Mexico, the Great Wall of China and the Acropolis in Greece (below). For those champing at the bit to attend the announcement ceremony, Abreu Tours is offering three-night and six-night packages, starting at $431 a person a night (double occupancy). Participants may choose from a variety of hotels, with optional car rental and airfare (www.abreu-tours.com). Intrepid Travel, an adventure tourism company based in Australia, is offering six new family itineraries: Europe, Switzerland, Turkey, Morocco, Egypt and Nepal. The trips are geared toward children ages 6 to 17, and there is a maximum of two children per adult. Rates vary, and don't include airfare and some meals. The Nepal Family Adventure, for example, an 11-day trip that includes white-water rafting, a visit to a crocodile breeding center, elephant rides and camping in the Himalayas, costs $830 a person (www.intrepidtravel.com). An Avis promotion (www.avis.com) is doubling the number of free iTunes downloads with car rentals. Usually, a customer who rents a vehicle for five days or more receives 10 downloads, but through June, customers get 20.

docs.lead_paragraph: From the fountain pen to the word processor, writers have always embraced technology to make their task less arduous. Mark Twain was an early enthusiast of the typewriter, and his ''Life on the Mississippi'' is believed to be the first typewritten literary manuscript. ''The machine has several virtues,'' he remarked of his Remington. ''I believe it will print faster than I can write.'' Today, most novelists don't venture beyond the word processor -- and many still write longhand. But others are finding that sophisticated software is invaluable to the literary enterprise. While Dickens and George Eliot had only notebooks and their wits to keep their Victorian triple-deckers in order, novelists like Richard Powers, Vikram Chandra and Marisha Pessl have used everything from Excel spreadsheets to logistics programs like Microsoft Project to organize their imaginative universes. To them, computer technology isn't a threat to literature but an essential tool. ''As life becomes increasingly complex, the kind of novel that tries to link the individual life with broad-canvas collective existence becomes more difficult to coordinate,'' Powers wrote in an e-mail message -- or rather, dictated, since he uses the voice recognition software built into the Tablet PC operating system to compose everything, including his novels. Computer programs allow novelists ''to build up dense and interconnected views of the world they are recreating,'' he added.

headline.main: Get With the Program

docs.snippet: While Dickens had only his notebook and his wits, today’s novelists use software to keep track of their characters.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sony has a long and colorful history of failure on the Internet. But there has been a bright spot, one Sony operation -- Sony Online Entertainment, based in San Diego -- has built a legitimately innovative and successful Internet business. Think of it as Sony's other video game operation. The ups and downs of the company's famous PlayStation division are well known, as it struggles to maintain its dominance in home consoles over Microsoft and Nintendo. But tucked within the relative obscurity of Sony Pictures Digital Entertainment, the online entertainment unit has grown into a profitable business with revenue in the $150 million range (the company does not break out exact results for the division) by creating and publishing a variety of subscription-based online computer games.

headline.main: Sony's Other Games Division Makes Push in New Direction
